SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum, and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Late last year, this Parliament passed the Privacy Act 1988. That Act provided for the establishment of the office of the Federal Privacy Commissioner and for privacy protection for individuals, both in relation to information about them held by Commonwealth agencies and in relation to their tax file numbers.

The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 is the next step in the Government's program to introduce comprehensive privacy protection for the Australian community. The principal purpose of this Bill is to provide privacy protection for individuals in relation to their consumer credit records.

It is generally accepted that individuals have the right to have certain data protection principles applying to large collections of sensitive personal data. The OECD Guidelines on Personal Privacy, which Australia has adhered to, set out these basic principles. These principles are:
there should be limits to the collection of personal data and any such data should be obtained by lawful and fair means with the knowledge or consent of the data-subject
personal data should be relevant to the purposes for which it is to be used and should be accurate
the purposes for which personal data is collected should be specified at the time of collection and subsequent use limited to the fulfilment of these purposes
personal data should not be disclosed for other purposes except with the consent of the data subject or where required by law
personal data should be protected by security safeguards
individuals should be aware who holds their personal data
individuals should have a right of access to and correction of their personal data
a data controller should be accountable for complying with measures to give effect to these principles.

These principles were adopted in the Privacy Act for application to Commonwealth agencies and to all tax file number users. This Bill adopts these principles to provide privacy protection for individuals in relation to their personal information which is held by the consumer credit reporting industry.

Central credit information databanks provide information to credit providers to assist decision making on the desirability of granting consumer credit. These databases, without proper supervision, hold considerable potential for privacy intrusion. Proposed new industry practices for credit profiling of individuals would have increased the dangers for privacy intrusion.

At the present time, there are inadequate controls on consumer credit reporting agencies to prevent them from using their databases for non consumer credit purposes. The development of comprehensive commitment profiles would increase the danger of information held by credit reporting agencies being used in unauthorised circumstances by bodies such as employers and private inquiry agents. It would also increase the potential for use of credit records for non-credit purposes, eg insurance proposals, insurance fraud, rental housing, occupational licensing-uses that clearly breach privacy principles.

The Australian Law Reform Commission's Privacy Report, which was tabled in this Parliament in late 1983, found that many members of the Australian community saw credit reporting agencies as posing a threat to privacy. A detailed public opinion poll carried out by the ALRC on attitudes to privacy ranked credit reporting agencies at the head of the list of potentially intrusive organisations. The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card viewed with concern the lack of regulation and the potential for infringement of civil liberties in relation to personal information held by credit reporting agencies.

The large majority of individuals meet their credit commitments. In determining the appropriate form of privacy regulation for the credit reporting industry, what must be paramount is the fundamental right of these individuals to privacy. However, this must be balanced against both the need for businesses to operate efficiently, and the right of credit providers to protect their commercial interests. Also, the welfare of those borrowers who may get into difficulties or who are led into difficulties must not be forgotten. This Bill achieves that difficult balance.

The Bill establishes a privacy framework for the regulation of the consumer credit reporting industry. The Privacy Commissioner will be given a clear legislative mandate to develop a Code of Conduct with the industry. The Code will provide a flexible and co-operative mechanism for the industry and community to give effect to the Bill. The Bill sets out a set of provisions which will regulate the collection, storage, access to, correction of, use and disclosure of personal credit information by credit providers and credit reporting agencies. Only those businesses which are providers of consumer credit will be allowed to have access to the consumer credit reporting system.

All records of personal information held at credit reporting agencies and information from central agencies held by credit providers such as banks, credit unions, finance companies and major retailers will be covered by the new legislation.

The Code of Conduct will be a major feature of the regulatory scheme for the consumer credit reporting industry. The Code will apply to information held in, or disseminated from, a central database and to the transfer of information between industry participants. The Privacy Act will provide statutory backing for the Code and will direct the Commissioner, in developing the Code of Conduct, to use, as his benchmark, the Information Privacy Principles set out in the Privacy Act. The Code will be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny as a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and will be published in the Gazette.
The Bill will provide individuals with an enforceable right of access to, and correction of, their credit records.

The Bill will provide that a credit report, held by a central reporting agency, will only be available to a credit provider when an application for credit is made. Credit providers will have to seek the consent of a client before they can disclose personal information to another credit provider unless there are reasonable grounds to believe that fraud may exist. The Privacy Commissioner will oversight the development of appropriate forms of consent. An important aspect of the Government's proposed regulation is that there will be strict requirements for consent before consumer credit information can be sought or passed on. Such information is often passed at the moment without the consent or knowledge of the consumer. The new controls will mean that consumers will be able to have authority over information about themselves. Credit providers will be able to continue to maintain their own information on their clients.

The information that a credit reporting agency can hold about an individual will be set out in the Bill. Basically, a credit reporting agency will be able to hold the information that they currently hold, ie. information about an individual's previous bad debts and information about enquiries by credit providers. Over time, a credit reporting agency will be required to delete information which it is no longer permitted to hold.

The Bill also limits access to consumer credit files so that only legitimate use is made of the information stored. This will mean that some current members of the leading consumer credit reporting agency, the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA), will no longer have access to consumer credit information files. Such users include private investigators, real estate agencies and insurance companies. Government departments and agencies which are not credit providers would also be prevented from using credit reference files, except by exercising statutory powers.
Positive Reporting

Community concerns with the credit industry have recently been heightened by industry's proposals for the introduction of a new and much more comprehensive form of credit reporting, namely positive reporting.

This would have meant the development of a system reporting comprehensively on a person's credit history regardless of new loan applications or defaults on a payment. Under this positive reporting system everybody who uses consumer credit in any form, such as credit cards or personal loans, would have had a monthly statement on their account provided by credit providers to a central national database operated by a central agency. Credit providers would supply the reporting agency with computer tapes of all their customers' credit accounts. These tapes would be merged with the central database, usually every 60 days. Credit providers would receive a report listing all known credit accounts, the balance owing on each account and its currency.
The credit reporting agency would effectively become a central clearing house of information about the current financial commitments of all Australians.

Positive reporting would constitute a major change in the level of information collected on individuals. While the notion of information collected in a centralised agency is not new, the collection of personal information on individuals' spending habits is-credit and spending profiles of individuals would have been built up through all their credit transactions.

The Government does not consider that there is any proven substantial benefit from positive reporting proposals. In view of this strong privacy concerns make any such expansion impossible to condone. The Government recognises that consumer credit reporting can be a useful adjunct to sound lending practices. Such reporting is not and should not be a substitute for this. The Government therefore does not believe that the collection of much more extensive information about individuals is an effective way to reduce consumers' credit overcommitment.

Also, the difficulties for banks in participating in such a scheme because of the confidentiality of their banker/client relationship, and the restrictive nature of the proposed scheme, weighed against the acceptance of positive reporting by the Government.

The way to reduce consumer credit overcommitment is not positive reporting. The Government and the community must continue to focus on education, appropriate counselling and most importantly on responsible lending practices. This is even truer in a society where the use of credit is fast becoming a normal part of living, and where credit options proliferate.

I should make it clear that it is not the intention of this Bill to restrict the use of commercial credit information by credit providers or credit reporting agencies. The Bill will prevent a commercial credit record of a small businessman or sole trader being used when assessing an application by them for credit which is for domestic consumer purpose.

The Privacy Commissioner will have an array of functions to protect the individual's privacy. He will be able to investigate complaints, proceed with own motion inquiries into credit providers and reporting agencies' practices in relation to the handling of information, and undertake random audits of credit providers and credit reporting agencies' databases to ensure their adherence to the Act and the Code of Conduct.
The credit provider or the credit reporting agency will handle complaints in the first instance. The Privacy Commissioner will only handle those complaints that cannot be resolved by industry.

The Privacy Commissioner has been given a range of mechanisms to enforce the privacy standards set out in the Act and in the Code of Conduct. A major role of the Commissioner will be to conciliate matters which involve a breach of the Act or the Code. The Commissioner will also be able to make a determination that an individual be paid damages as compensation by a credit provider or credit reporting agency which has misused the individual's personal credit information. There are also offence provisions carrying stringent penalties for individuals or companies that seek to obtain unauthorised access to credit records, or that intentionally or negligently supply false credit information or misuse credit information.

The Bill will provide individuals with comprehensive privacy protection for their credit records. It will provide an enforceable right of access to credit records and a practical means for individuals who have been adversely affected by misuse of the credit information to seek redress.

The legislative charter set out in the Bill, which will be further elaborated in the Code of Conduct, provides a balanced recognition of the interests of both lenders and borrowers. It pays proper regard to the issues of privacy and data protection. In particular, it seeks to meet data protection requirements that information should be obtained and processed fairly. It also meets the principles that information should be relevant for the purpose for which it is held, it should not intrude to an unreasonable extent upon the personal affairs of individuals and it should not be used for incompatible purposes without the consent of the individual.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate turns to debating the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill establishes the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) and defines its functions and powers. The Commission will hold public inquiries and inform and advise the Government on matters relating to the use of resources and involving consideration of conservation and development issues.

The job of the Resource Assessment Commission will be to assemble all reasonably available information, acknowledge those areas where uncertainty remains, take relevant viewpoints into account and advise the Government on the options it can adopt within a reasonable timeframe. Although I am addressing these remarks to the Senate, I really would have liked to address them to the back bench of the Australian Labor Party and to the members of the Australian Democrats. I say to them now that the basic concepts and objectives of this legislation have much merit but, like a lot of legislation which has been rushed into this chamber, there are flaws within the Bill.

I remind the Senate how many times it has held up legislation while people have been able to make representations or the Senate has referred a Bill to one of its committees for consideration, and how many times after some short delay legislation has come back into the Parliament in a much better form. I point, in particular, to a piece of legislation which will be coming up for debate later today, the Patents Amendment Bill, which was rushed into this chamber 12 months ago. We had to get it through before the winter recess. It was absolutely essential that it go through, notwithstanding the fact that it had been four years in preparation. It had to be rushed through before June of last year, but the Democrats joined with the coalition in refusing to allow the Government to rush the legislation through, and 12 months later the Government has brought it back with a lot of amendments of its own which have greatly improved the Bill. Similarly, a patents Bill was brought into this place in December of 1987. It had to be carried before Christmas. It was absolutely essential that it come into operation on 1 January 1988. Again the Democrats joined with the coalition in deferring that legislation so that representatives of interested parties could make representation. The Government did not bring the Bill back until about April or May of this year, and it brought it back with an enormous number of changes which greatly improved the legislation.

I say to the back bench of the Government and particularly to members of the Australian Democrats that this Bill is in precisely the same condition. It needs to be considered by a legislative committee which can look at its implications and how it will operate. If the Democrats are not concerned about the issues I am raising with them, they should look at their own amendments. They should look at what is set out on the third page, in amendment (5), which is to insert certain principles. The second principle states:
Resource use decisions should seek to optimise the net benefits to the community from the nation's resources, having regard to efficiency of resource use, environmental considerations . . .

I am not arguing that anything is wrong with that, but it then refers to `ecological integrity'. I am sure that Senator Sanders knew what he meant by `ecological integrity' when he drafted his amendment or he thinks he does. Then there is a reference to `sustain- ability'. What on earth does that mean? I am sure Senator Sanders knows what he thinks it means, but is he sure that the courts will know what he meant by it when they come to interpret this legislation? The second principle then refers to `ecosystem integrity and sustainability'. Again he uses that word. I do not know whether `sustainability' is in the Oxford Dictionary, but I doubt very much whether it has been interpreted by the High Court of Australia. The second principle then goes on to talk about `the sustainability of any development and an equitable distribution of the return on resources'. I have no doubt that Senator Sanders, as I have said, knows what he means by that.

The Australian Democrats are proposing to amend the legislation and add these words to one of the fundamental principles of the Bill, but I say to the Democrats that they cannot be sure of the interpretation of their proposed legislation. Just because Senator Sanders has done some deal with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) there is no reason for them not to reconsider that deal that has been done and say to the Government, `Well, we would like to have one of the Senate standing committees look at this piece of legislation'. We will be moving an amendment, which by now should have been distributed, to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. The amendment states:

Leave out all words after ``That'', insert, ``the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, for inquiry and report, on or before the first sitting day in September 1989, on the meaning and implications of the Bill and its Schedules, with particular reference to:

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Lewis, are you moving that amendment formally?

—No, I am not actually moving it. I am reading it out. I will move it in my own good time. The amendment goes on to list particular references. If the Australian Democrats wish to add to the particulars, I would be happy to consider amending them by adding some of the words indicated in their amendment. I now formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after ``That'', insert, ``the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, for inquiry and report, on or before the first sitting day in September 1989, on the meaning and implications of the Bill and its Schedules, with particular reference to:
(a) its effects on the rights of the States in general and in relation to water rights in particular;
(b) the ability of States or Territories to initiate a resource matter;
(c) whether or not the Inter-State Commission should have a role pursuant to section 101 of the Constitution;
(d) the definitions of `resource' and `resource matter'; and
(e) whether any qualifications should be necessary for appointment as a special Commissioner.''.

As I said, the coalition parties believe that the basic concept and objectives of this Bill have much merit. But there are shortcomings. I have referred to what I believe are shortcomings which the Democrats are aware of. Let me go on and talk about some of the problems which we see in the legislation. We see major problems with the definition of the word `resource' and the words `resource matter'. We believe these definitions are so broad that they must create constitutional problems. The word `resource' is defined as follows:
``resource'' means a biological mineral or other material component, whether natural or not (other than a human being), and includes a permanent or temporary combination or association of components;

The term `resource matter' has a long definition relating to the use of a resource. As I said, these terms are so broad that in our view they may very well raise constitutional questions. Section 99 of the Constitution prevents the Commonwealth from giving a preference to one State or any part thereof. Clearly, the Resource Assessment Commission could recommend that a forest in one State, say in southern New South Wales, be logged but that a forest in another State not be logged. Would the implementation of that recommendation not infringe State rights? Would it not infringe the Constitution? If so, would the Inter-State Commission have a role in the adjudication and administration of that problem? The Bill does not face up to these questions in any way. Clause 16 of the Bill states:
Where the Commonwealth Government or a Commonwealth authority may, in the exercise of its powers-
I emphasise the words `in the exercise of its powers'-
make a decision in relation to a resource matter, the Minister may, by written notice to the Chairperson, require the Commission to conduct an inquiry into the matter.

Where are the Commonwealth's constitutional powers defined in relation to resources? This action is taken in the exercise of its powers. Under which placitum of section 51 of the Constitution are the Commonwealth's constitutional powers in relation to resources? I refer to another problem. Water is clearly within the definition of resource in this Bill, but section 100 of the Constitution provides:

The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade or commerce, abridge the right of a State or of the residents therein to the reasonable use of the waters of rivers for conservation or irrigation.

What happens if there is a recommendation in relation to the use of waters or rivers? What happens if that recommendation abridges the right of a State or the residents of a State in relation to the use of those waters for those purposes? The Bill does not address that problem. It is a matter which ought to be taken into consideration. Further, nowhere in the Bill is there any recognition given to the sovereignty of the States. Although the Minister claims in his second reading speech that the Bill provides opportunities for participation by all interested parties, including States, the Bill makes no provision for a State exercising its sovereign rights to initiate an inquiry or reject the recommendations of the Commission.

What happens if a State, acting constitutionally, chooses to reject a Commonwealth decision? What happens if the Minister refers a resource matter to the Commission without consultation with the State government and it decides not to cooperate? This Bill does not provide the answers. I ask the Minister whether the Commission will have the power to subpoena a State Minister to give evidence under clause 36. What is the position if the Commission seeks confidential State Cabinet documents? What is the position of, say, a State director of forests or mining if he or she is subpoenaed to appear before the Commission but is then ordered by the State Minister not to appear or not to supply documents? The Bill does not indicate the answers to those problems.

Are the special commissioners not required to have any qualifications? That is not set out in this Bill. Is that right? Should they not have any qualifications? These are matters which a Senate committee could apply its mind to. In regard to confidentiality of State Cabinet documents, should there not be some protection for commercial in-confidence documents or evidence being provided by businesses? They may have to give evidence about capital investments. They may be required to give evidence about their projected profits. Should that not be treated as a commercial in-confidence matter? Should they not be protected by the Act? I know what the Minister will say. He will say, `It will be up to the Chairperson of the Commission to make that decision'. Does the Minister really think that that is adequate? What about evidence relating to new technology or techniques? Some companies may have new ideas about the use of a resource and they may not wish to disclose that publicly. It may be a type of technique or technology which they do not want to patent but which they wish to keep confidential. How will they be able to do that under this Bill? Again, I suppose the Minister will say, `That will be up to the Chairperson'. Is that correct? Are we going to subject Australian businesses to the whims of the Chairperson in this matter or are we going to provide in the legislation protection for these people?

I am not telling the Minister what the answers are. I am merely saying that these are the sorts of problems which the Government has not addressed. Once again, this Government has rushed in this legislation in order to be seen to be doing something before the next election. It is panicking. It is saying, `There is an election coming up and we are down in the polls. We look as if we might get beaten. Let's do something. There is a greenie vote out there. Let's rush out and grab the greenie vote. How can we do that? We will do that by introducing this piece of legislation. It will solve our problems in the forests'. What about the Democrat amendment, which I understand the Government has accepted, which seeks to ensure that only sustainable resources can be used? Does that mean we will not be able to mine gold because once it is taken out of the ground, it has gone? I can understand that in relation to--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it doing to the environment? That is the whole point.

—Senator Sanders is saying, `That is the whole point'. So he is going along with what I am saying. If we take the gold out of the ground, it is finished. I can understand Senator Sanders saying, `You do not cut down trees unless you are also planting trees'. That would make that resource sustainable. But what about resources that are mined? No-one would have any clue as to the meaning of the words `the sustainability of any development' used by Senator Sanders in his amendment. He wants this to refer to ecological integrity and sustainability. Dear, oh dear! They are words which ought to be looked at by a parliamentary committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it reasonable that the Parliament should enact this legislation without addressing these questions? Of course it is not reasonable. But, as I have indicated-and it is clear from the interjections from Senator Sanders and Senator Richardson-the Australian Democrats have done a deal with the Government to pass this Bill with a few amendments-amendments which will add to the burden of Australian taxpayers. This enables the Government to avoid addressing matters of great importance and may very well assist Senator Sanders in his next election campaign in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). We understand that he is to become No. 2 on the Australian Labor Party (ALP) ticket for the ACT. This deal probably has much more to do with Senator Sanders's deal with the ALP for the next election than with the resources of this nation.

Once again, the Democrats are enabling the Government to get away with a badly drafted Bill which ignores many fundamental questions. This legislation, in its imperfect form, with the hard questions left unresolved, is more likely to end in costly litigation and bitter wrangling between Federal and State governments while extremists exploit the Australian Democrat amendments to feather their own nests. The coalition parties believe that a Senate standing committee is the proper body to look at the questions I have raised. Accordingly, I have moved the circulated amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot to reply to in what Senator Lewis said. I will start off with `sustainability'; that seems to be one of his sticking points. Perhaps he is right. Perhaps it would be a good idea to have a committee look at one thing-not necessarily the Resource Assessment Commission Bill but the concept of sustainability and other matters, as has been presented in a book entitled Our Own Future, of which apparently Senator Lewis is not aware. This is actually the report of the Royal Commission on Environment and Development. It is called the Brundtland report; it is named after its Chairman, Gro Harlem Brundtland, who is the Prime Minister of Norway.

SPEECH.PARA: This book is universally considered to be a well reasoned plan for the survival of the human race in the late twentieth century and beyond. It spells out `sustainability'. I quote from chapter 2 on page 43, headed `Towards Sustainable Development':
Sustainable development is development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. It contains within it two key concepts:
the concept of `needs', in particular the essential needs of the world's poor, to which overriding priority should be given; and
the idea of limitations imposed by the state of technology and social organisation on the environment's ability to meet present and future needs.

We are trying to preserve the environment not for its own sake but so that it can support us, or provide a habitat for human beings. I am sure that Senator Lewis would like to continue to live on this earth and I am sure that his children and his children's children would like to live on this earth. But it is becoming increasingly obvious that what we are doing to our habitat is not sustainable; that it will not sustain our life. I think Senator Lewis would agree with that. That is the definition. There is no argument with that.

`Ecological integrity' is the same. We have a definition for that. We do not need to have a committee. I rather doubt that a committee could arrive at decisions of these sorts. I do not think a committee would be capable of it.

As I read the amendment that Senator Lewis has moved, I find it basically preservation of States rights. If there is any one single factor that has kept Australia from becoming a major nation on the face of this earth it is States rights. We really need to eliminate the States and get on with the job of running this country as a single country. After all, its population is only 17 or 18 million people. Can we afford the luxury of all these petulant little States competing with each other to give away our resources, to sell off our woodchips, to sell off coal at the cheapest price and to sell off power? No; we need a federally planned economy and environmental policy to deal with the problems. These problems do not stop at State borders. They cross State lines and they should be dealt with federally.

I do not know where the shadow Minister for the environment and the arts is during this debate. Where is Senator Puplick? Senator Lewis is capably carrying this debate but I thought Senator Puplick was interested in the environment and was hoping to become the Minister for the environment in the Liberal Government, if there ever is one. I expected him to be speaking in this debate but he is not. The Opposition has moved an amendment. The Australian Democrats will not support it. We feel that it is nothing but another sop to those who would put States rights ahead of the development of the nation.

Let me get on with the Bill itself. We feel that the Bill is a step in the right direction. To be completely on the right track, the new commission should not be called the Resource Assessment Commission; it should be called the Environment Assessment Commission. I think it is time that we reversed the onus of proof. We are still getting into the situation where development is assumed to be a good thing. The environmental arguments then have to be put up to show that the environmental damage will be so great that the development should not go ahead. I think the environment should be put first. Any development should be considered to be harmful to the environment, which it is, and the developers should be forced to argue their case rather than the environmentalists mount their argument. This Bill is a step in the right direction.

At the moment, Government decisions are often based on data which is not complete and is often biased. Much of the data that the Government receives is from industry because it has the facilities and it can hire the consultants. Much of the information comes from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy rather than the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. This means that it is biased, and rightly so. If the Department is in the business of promoting industry, and if primary industry is part of the Minister's portfolio, why not be biased in the direction of industry? It is biased in this direction. It is up to the environment movement to lobby as hard as it can on every issue to try to get some balance. This decision to set up the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) will, I hope, redress that by allowing another agency to look at these decisions.

We in the environmental movement have had a number of misgivings about this Bill. One of the greatest ones was that the mining and timber industries and the National Farmers Federation seem to support it wholeheartedly. This is a worry. I do not think it is enough of a worry to vote against the Bill merely because these people support it. Maybe they do not understand it fully. Another worry to the environmental movement is that we would be put in the position of continually making submissions, as in the case of the Helsham Committee of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, which saps the strength and the financial resources-which are somewhat meagre-of the environmental movement. We do not want to have to be put in the position where we are constantly responding to the requirements of a commission for information. Another worry was the pro-development bias on the commission itself. Under the Act, the Industries Assistance Commission and the Australian Science and Technology Council would be involved in appointing the commissioners.

The Industries Assistance Commission by its very name is development oriented. The Australian Science and Technology Council has often shown itself to be development oriented. We addressed these problems and approached the Government. We arrived with a package of amendments, which will be moved in the committee stage, which go a long way to convincing us that this will be a worthwhile commission once it is established. One of our major amendments is that when a matter relates to the National Estate, the Australian Heritage Commission shall give evidence about the matter to the inquiry. This is a mechanism for giving the Australian Heritage Commission, which is very much concerned with the environment, an input into the Resource Assessment Commission.

Another amendment involves creating a mechanism so that people who testify before the Commission can be reimbursed for their expenses in travelling to the hearings and, in certain cases, can be remunerated for the development of data. It reads expressly:

If the chairperson considers it appropriate a person who gives evidence to or produces documents at an inquiry may be paid such remuneration as is prescribed for the performance of work involved in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents.

This is very important because, unlike the mining industry, the timber industry and all the development interests in general, environmentalists work in their spare time. They have to have other employment to support themselves. They cannot just pay vast amounts of money, as the developers can, for their data. They cannot hire consultants. So this amendment goes a long way towards making the fight more fair so that the environmental movement can come up with information to counteract that of the developers.

The other set of amendments has already been referred to by Senator Lewis. They involve the concepts of sustainability, ecological integrity and the other things I have already mentioned which basically flow from the Brundtland report. After all, this is only common sense. If we intend to live on this earth for any length of time, we must take care of our habitat. We have not been doing so to this point.

The Resource Assessment Commission will go a long way towards resolving our difficulties. It should come up with enough data so that we can finally resolve the difficulties inherent in the timber industry. The first reference, I understand, will be a reference about the timber industry, to look at sustainability, to look at plantations, to study alternatives to present practices. This is imperative because, although what is happening in the south-east forests of New South Wales is at the focus of our attention now, forestry all over the country needs to be considered.

The Bill is timely. We have entered a new environmental era. The people of the world are demanding environmental action. The days of confrontation may be coming to an end. I sincerely hope that they are. I do not like going out and getting arrested in forests. No-one does. Confrontation is a stopgap measure. It is not the final solution. We must feel that we are working together on these matters. The RAC will give us that opportunity. Our present environmental problems are now so serious that we have to try every possible mechanism to halt the destruction of our habitat. We support the Bill. We do not support the Opposition amendments. We foreshadow amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the principle of the Resource Assessment Commission Bill but I have some problems with the content of it, particularly now that the Government has done a pretty sordid deal with the Australian Democrats to make this Bill, it seems to me, much less effective and certainly much more subject to absurd pressure in its amended form. The deal done with the Democrats underlines the need for this otherwise sound proposal to be subjected to the detailed scrutiny of a Senate committee. There is no doubt that the significant changes being imposed on the Bill by the Australian Democrats as part of the deal to get it through will disadvantage those projects that should proceed and disadvantage the structure of the proposed Resource Assessment Commission (RAC). Some of us took the initial response that the Resource Assessment Commission proposal must be a good idea because Senator Sanders in particular initially vehemently opposed it. If Senator Sanders opposes something it is per se clearly of benefit. I quote from Senator Sanders's press release earlier this month on the Resource Assessment Commission Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that the RAC would be of great benefit to the developers in their efforts to rip off Australia's environment. The Opposition has always supported the developers rather than the environment. It looks like they are running true to form.
Senator Sanders pointed out:
. . . the RAC would enable the Government to side-step difficult environmental decisions by referring them to a Commission.
This is the same Senator Sanders who has just given a speech in support of the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did a deal.
—That is absolutely right. Senator Sanders did a deal which damages the fabric of the legislation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only will the RAC protect the Government from public pressure, but the RAC itself will inevitably be development oriented through its Commissioners being appointed by the Industries Assistance Commission and the Australian Science and Technology Council.

Quite frankly, the amendment that the Australian Democrats have moved does not change that part of Senator Sanders's objection. For him to come in here and say, `We have done a deal' which makes the Bill acceptable to him means that we have to examine very closely indeed the vehement original objection which has now been replaced by his endorsement. That is one of the reasons why it is absolutely vital that this legislation which, as I have said, was sound in principle and which in fact embraces quite a few of the policy thrusts of the coalition's resources policy, must now be sent to a Senate committee to find out, apart from anything else, why Senator Sanders is so happy about it. All Australians should twitch every time Senator Sanders comes out in strong support of something, particularly something that until very recently he has strongly opposed. Those changes must be examined.

There is no doubt that the industries involved are in favour of a Resource Assessment Commission, and sensibly so. They have been mucked around and the people of Australia have suffered the financial consequences of a succession of irresponsible, unfounded and unsustainable attacks on almost every development without those attacks being presented and judged in any competent forum. One can hardly call the Cabinet room of this Government a competent forum, because that is where the decisions have had to be taken.

This Commission will require those people who make these mad protests, and whose volume of noise has been the prime factor in influencing decisions, to come before a skilled forum where their case will be examined by people who know what they are doing. The bluster and nonsense we continually hear from Senator Sanders and his friends in this place will be tested in that forum. I hope the volume of noise and of political expediency which has been so prominent in the past will no longer be a factor. The Resource Assessment Commission will simply be an adviser to the Government, which can then continue to take its politically expedient decisions as it does. But at least the case will be argued, as with the Industries Assistance Commission, on the public record for people to see just how expedient the Government has been in making a decision which is not in line with the recommendations of the RAC.

To give an indication of the sort of support for the principle of the thing, it is evident that the National Farmers Federation, for example, has consistently sought a formal balance in the way land use decisions are handled by the Government. It welcomed the decision of the Government to establish the Resource Assessment Commission. The same goes for the National Association of Forest Industries and the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC).

Frankly, the key point is that Mr Kerin and Senator Cook, the two Government Ministers having resource portfolios, had to do something to create order out of the chaos being created by Senator Richardson in his sudden discovery of the joys of being green. Knowing Senator Richardson's background, his motivation is no doubt closely connected to his capacity to count the numbers. Senator Richardson is renowned throughout Australia as a very competent political animal. He has recognised the political reality of the need to attract votes from those people who quite genuinely are concerned about the environment. But on the other side of that coin Mr Kerin and Senator Cook who are responsible for Australia being able to survive the economic crisis it is now in-and that task will be difficult-have recognised that there is a clear need to reduce the impact of electoral environmental policies on issues of national economic importance so that they can be discussed and decisions taken in a rational and coherent way which examines the sometimes hysterically false, but nonetheless on the surface plausible, case being put up by people like Senator Sanders, who are much more full of noise than fact in so many of the matters that they raise.

As the National Farmers Federation said, clearly the Bill does not stem from Senator Richardson's office. It certainly does not reflect the hand of the environmental movement which widely attacked it. The Australian Conservation Foundation and other conservation groups did not even accept an invitation from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to attend a review of the draft legislation. There were some problems with the legislation even before the Australian Democrats made such a mess of it in this deal with the Government. Clearly, there is an attack on States rights--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not wrong.

—Senator Crichton-Browne says, `You're not wrong'. Many people take the view, as I certainly do, that it is absolutely vital to maintain States rights, not for any historic reason but because of the simple practical fact that it is vital to divide power in Australia and not let it be concentrated in one set of hands. The old axiom of Lord Acton that power tends to corrupt and absolute power tends to corrupt absolutely is as apposite now as it was at the beginning of the century. It is notable that when States have powers in a federal structure there is a diminished prospect of centralised power being used improperly and dictatorship emerging. It is notable that after the war the Americans imposed a federal republic structure on West Germany to ensure that power would not be centralised in one set of hands. I must say that there are some people in this Government I would not like to see with absolute power.
—A little bit is dangerous for them.

—Even with the little they have they are dangerous enough. The discussion about whether or not there should be States rights must be seen in the context of whether Australians want people such as Mr Keating to have absolute power over all governmental activities in Australia, or whether they would rather have perhaps a slightly less efficient system under which power was limited and those politicians who sought to exercise that kind of absolute power-sometimes, one feels, not necessarily for the benefit of the people of Australia-were prevented from doing so. Every member of this Parliament should recognise that there is a real need to preserve and protect the institution of State governments to ensure that power is spread and not allowed to collect in too few hands, enabling it to be exercised to the disadvantage of Australians in an authoritarian way. So often we see that governments around the world-for example, the Government of China-have centralised power: no effective State system and no splitting up of the power. For instance, in Australia the police are under the control of State governments but the Army is under the control of the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt in my mind that the Bill impinges on the rights and powers of the States. I believe it is wrong that the Bill does not require at least consultation with the States on this matter because, after all, the States do have and must have the right to determine the use of their resources. There are some problems in that area. That is another matter that the Opposition proposes, quite properly, to refer to the Senate committee.

The Opposition is concerned about the confidentiality provisions. We do not think that they have been coped with adequately. That matter will be dealt with at the committee stage of the Bill. There is one thing I would commend in view of the fact that the Government's organisations have behaved so appallingly in reporting to the Parliament-that is, the Bill requires that the Commission prepare an annual report and that the Minister table the report within 25 days of its receipt. That is a much overdue change for the better and I hope that the Commission will meet that obligation.

The Resource Assessment Commission Bill does not even recognise the primary role of the States in land use questions, let alone allow them a role in referring projects for inquiry, or even helping in the selection of special commissioners and consultants. The States, therefore, are concerned that the terms of reference could be loaded. The Bill imposes yet another layer of bureaucratic delay on resource industries. Nonetheless, the thrust of the legislation is to the advantage of the resource industries in the sense that they can discuss these matters in a clear forum and a balanced and non-emotive assessment of land use issues in such a forum is certainly, as the AMIC pointed out, far preferable to the ad hoc approach which has prevailed under this Government in recent years. The Mining Industry Council says that there have been:
. . . outrageous claims in relation to environmental impact, without any risk that those claims will have to be justified before an independent scientific inquiry.
That was evident in the Wesley Vale pulp mill debate. AMIC says:

This has resulted in a series of increasingly important setbacks for the resource industries, including exploration rights in Kakadu Stage I, Stage II and most of Stage III; the Queensland Wet Tropics World Heritage Listing, and the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests decision. Areas currently under siege include the Kakadu Conservation Zone, the New South Wales Southern Forests, the Nullarbor and the Kimberley.

AMIC considers that the prospect of balanced land use decisions reflecting multiple land use philosophies and the concept of sustainable development would be enhanced by the establishment of the Resource Assessment Commission. I agree with that, provided that the Commission's behaviour is rational and it is staffed by Mr Kerin and Senator Cook and not Senator Richardson.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only this Government that makes this Bill necessary in the first place.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, it is only the behaviour of this Government that makes it necessary to introduce such a Bill. As AMIC points out, the behaviour of the Government in the last few years has created the tensions and uncertainties that make the Bill necessary. The Opposition, as I said, is concerned about questions of consultation with the States and confidentiality of evidence at the request of the witness. AMIC says it supports these amendments. It should, because they are sensible and would improve the working of the Bill. The Australian Democrats change of heart on this should be a matter of major concern to all Australians because they had indicated clear opposition. Their motive for opposing it at that time was undoubtedly, as AMIC says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . their awareness that the intellectual capacity and effort needed to establish conservation arguments within the context of better mechanisms is far greater than that involved in gaining media exposure, organising demonstrations and making extreme and unchallenged claims.

That is one of the reasons I strongly support the principle of this Bill. One would hope that environmental issues, when they affect development, would be discussed in an environment in which rational and coherent behaviour would predominate, rather than the argument of the demonstration, the noise, the extreme and the unchallenged claims which simply cannot be sustained.

Another point with respect to the requirement for such a Bill is that it is always open to the Government to initiate an environmental inquiry under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. That Act contains none of the safeguards provided for the Resource Assessment Commission. There is no doubt that the Commission is a better way of dealing with the matter than the legislative arrangements presently available to the Government.

Finally, I wish to deal very briefly with the amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats which are absolutely ludicrous. For example, there is no definition of the word `sustainability' in the Bill. Sustainability is a matter of such substance that Senator Sanders directed our attention to a book in which it is defined. When Senator Sanders gets around to defining sustainability in the legislation so that it has some binding effect, we could look at his amendments with a little more equanimity. We have no idea what is meant by that. We have no idea of what is meant by an `equitable' distribution on return of resources. The questions raised by these amendments are so great that they must be referred to a committee for this legislation to be coherent. For example, the amendment says that a person who gives evidence to or produces documents at an inquiry may be paid such remuneration as is prescribed. I ask who will prescribe it and, further, why is the word `reasonable' excluded from that part of the amendment. The word `reasonable' appears in the second part where it says that a person should be reimbursed such expenses, or compensated for such losses, as were reasonably incurred'. There need be no reasonableness about the remuneration prescribed.

There is a real risk of an open-ended cheque-basically an employment cheque-to be given to environmentalists to generate a profession of objecting to proposals. Those professional objectors will be paid for by the taxpayers of Australia. It is absolutely incredible. Already the Government provides multi-millions of dollars to the conservation movement in one way or another--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which some of them have used to campaign against their own party.

—That is right. Some of the money has been washed through other conservation bodies and appears in campaign funds for elections, being used against the Opposition. In recent cases I understand that it also has been used against the Labor Party. It seems absolutely ludicrous that we are generating a profession of paid agitators who will receive a benefit by objecting to development projects in Australia, projects which are in the best economic interests of the people of Australia and which will, under this proposal, be subject to proper scrutiny. Why the Government should have agreed to allow for the payment of professional stirrers is beyond me. Surely there are better ways of making certain that the environmental case can be presented effectively rather than by this pay-off deal which has been done with the Democrats in order to pass this legislation without it being examined closely. This is an absolute disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that at this stage the Commission does have the appearance of being excessively legalistic. I have no derogatory comments about Mr Justice Stewart who will chair the Commission; the problem seems to be that a judicial appointment to that position is not necessarily an appropriate one in this area. To my knowledge Mr Justice Stewart has no professional expertise in resource matters. I would much rather have seen the appointment of a chairman who had general expertise in the resource use and planning area. As the chairman will be required to provide continuity between inquiries, it clearly is a vital appointment. The appointee needs to be more than impartial and experienced in the conduct of judicial inquiries. The chairman should be seeking to bring consensus. We have seen the outcome when there was not consensus in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry. The minority and majority reports meant that the Government was given very little guidance. The Government has to think more effectively about what it is trying to achieve with this legislation.

I conclude my remarks by saying that I strongly support the concept of the Resource Assessment Commission. I regret that the Labor Party has now so destroyed the integrity of that proposal by accepting the Democrats amendments to it that the matter should be sent to a committee for examination, even though that would cause delay in the passage of the legislation. It is such an important issue that we should be concentrating on getting it right, rather than on getting it through, no matter what the cost. That is the approach the Government has taken-getting it through no matter what the cost-by doing this deal with the Democrats. It has damaged the fabric of this legislation so significantly that Senator Sanders and his colleagues who totally opposed it at the outset are now prepared to support it. That is sufficient evidence to dramatise the importance of the Opposition's amendment referring the matter to a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleague Senator Michael Baume, I believe that the establishment of the Resource Assessment Commission has some merit. The concept of the Commission is to be supported as it embraces a great many of the coalition's own environmental policies. The Government should acknowledge that it has the support of the coalition as far as the concept and the objective of the Commission has been defined. However, the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989 has been brought into the Senate in haste. There are many gaps in the legislation. The drafting of it has been born out of the wrong reactions and for wrong reasons. Add to that the Australian Democrats' amendments, which I believe the Government will support, and the Bill has changed face. As the coalition amendment recommends, the matter should be taken to a Senate committee to answer many of the pressing questions, such as States rights. That is one of the most important unanswered questions in this Bill on which we are not satisfied. The Government should realise that there can be across the board support for the establishment of this Commission but, first, we must get it right; we must take it to a Senate committee and bring that committee's report back to this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Many questions have to be asked about the Democrats' proposed amendments. The coalition rejects them out of hand. In particular, I draw the Senate's attention to the payment by the Commonwealth of such expenses as travelling expenses and other costs-the costs of putting submissions together; the costs of who knows what-which should be examined by the Senate committee. Exactly how far and wide will these costs be? What are the limits? As Senator Baume pointed out, this has damaged the whole fabric and intent of the Commission. It is now not the same Bill that the coalition would support or, indeed, which the resource industries would support.

The resource industries got behind the basic concept of the Commission but now must also question its establishment, should this legislation be passed today. The reported role of the Commission in the early days was to hold inquiries in a similar manner to that of the Industries Assistance Commission. We have no argument with that. The aim was to establish and report to the Government on a far more balanced use of resources and to consider the question of genuine environmental concerns. In other words, the principles underlying the Commission stress the need for an integrated approach-something that Senator Sanders might have to come to grips with in the years to come-between the efficient use of our resources and the genuine, not extremist, conservationist concerns.

This Commission had a chance to integrate those two worthy concerns. Above all, it had the task of tackling these issues early before they came onto the political agenda, exploded into the media and political opportunist like Senator Sanders took hold of them in the spotlight of television-the 30-second grab-utterly distorting the argument. The Commission had a chance to be able to stop those types of media explosions, to get a proper, balanced and integrated argument on the table and be able to produce the facts and not the 30-second grabs on television. The Commission was going to be pro-active rather than reactive. This present situation is a product of the mess that the Government has created by allowing the environmental question to get right out of hand. The Government has been unable to mesh the two major concerns-to promote development and sustain the environment. Too often the Labor Government has found itself caught, due to its lack of cohesive national strategy, in a media war between the environmentalists and the mining or forestry industries.

The Government has been quite satisfied to lurch from issue to issue according to the political climate, making its decisions according to the political climate and what State or region the issue happens to be in. Almost invariably the extremist element of the conservationist movement has taken hold of the debate in a senseless manner. Each time, led by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) the Government has caved in to their demands and their radical claims.

It is worth again pointing out to the Government that the resource industries originally believed that the whole concept of this independent assessment commission was quite worthy. That is what we are looking for. That is what both sides of the chamber are looking for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters, please do not walk between the Chair and the speaker.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Walters was not a distraction. Senator Walters, I should say, is never a distraction to me. She is the greatest distraction to the Government, and I encourage her to keep up the good work she has put into this Parliament over many years. I am quite happy if she goes to the opposite side of the chamber to annoy and distract the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). Whatever she is lobbying for, I hope she gets it. She is a tireless worker in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure Senator Walters agrees with me in my condemnation of the Government and, above all, of the Australian Democrats. In essence they are the ones who have changed the face of this Commission. They are the ones condemned. They have now lost the support of the resource industries. All they have achieved is to put the extremist environmental groups on the gravy train. That is the essence of their amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is where they belong. Too long they have been labelled as--
—Senator Sanders says that is where they belong-extremist environmental groups belong on the government gravy train.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Sanders is to be condemned for that. There is absolutely no hope for him if that is the way he administers his public life. I hope that the people of the Australian Capital Territory are listening to Senator Sanders's interjections because he is on the gravy train if that is what he really believes-a sap on the taxpayers not worthy to be in this chamber. I think there is just a little bit more to public life than being on the gravy train but Senator Sanders has made it quite clear that that is what he is here for. Industry supports such as the National Association of Forest Industries--
—Do you want me to protect you, Senator Sanders?
—The Minister can protect him all he likes.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator McGauran referred to Senator Sanders as being in the Senate purely to be on the gravy train. I think that is offensive. Senator Sanders has been elected by the people of Tasmania to perform a task which he discharges honourably. The remark is just on the borderline of being offensive to an honourable senator in this chamber.
—I ask Senator McGauran to be aware of the provisions of standing order 418 which make unacceptable any imputation of improper motives.

—I certainly take that into account but I should add that Senator Sanders cannot really call himself a Tasmanian any more. He has left that State. That is by his own admission. I know he has said on radio that he has walked away from Tasmania, and people in that State have every right to be annoyed with him. He was the one who said he wanted to be on the gravy train. Let us go back and look at Hansard. I want to get back to this Bill. I do not want to be distracted by such irrelevancies as Senator Sanders. The types of groups that were interested in an independent commission were the National Association of Forest Industries, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council, the Australian Mining Industry Council and the National Farmers Federation. That is a pretty worthy group to support the independent commission. Their support was based on the fact that we would get a level headed forum where both views could be put on the table and the arguments could be studied intricately, properly and out of the heat of the media debate. That would certainly reduce the influence of the politics of opportunism which surrounds the conservation issue today and would reduce many extreme tactics of conservationists who attempt to simplify the argument within the 30-second grab on television or on the doorstep.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission was born out of the Wesley Vale debacle, in which probably sensible heads within the Government-the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and even the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook-believed that this country could not afford such senseless and simplistic disputes again. We simply could not afford it all because of our current account crisis. We had to address these problems to get the proper balance between the two parties. The result is a major defeat for Senator Richardson and his extremist greenies. There is no question about that. This Commission was a major defeat prior to the Democrats' amendments. One could say that Senator Richardson has come back from the grave now because the Government has turned this Commission into nothing more than the financing arm of the extremist greenies. The public should be made aware why such groups as the extremist greenies or the extremist conservationists or environmentalists-but extremists is what they are--

TALK.START.PARA: —A demagogue.
—I am a conservationist, I am a greenie, I am an environmentalist; but I am not an extremist. There is the difference.
—Do you support the mining industry?
—I support the mining industry. Does Senator Sanders support the mining industry?
—Not particularly.
—Not at all.
—Not until it cleans up its act.

—The original concept of the Commission was going to damage many a political green career, but it will certainly do wonders for a very rational debate in Australia regarding such matters. It was the last hope for the resource industries that there would be some rational debate in this country over such matters. The failure of the Commission will simply mean that many investments will be scrapped. That is now a real possibility due to the Democrats' proposed amendments and the fact that the Government will not concede that the matter should go to a Senate committee-not to be held up for 12 months; we do not want to hold it up. We want to look at certain very important points. We will have it back here by September if the Government likes. But there are very important points such as States rights and the formation of the Commission itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go through some of those matters. The membership of the Commission is all important. That is something that a Senate committee must look at. It would be a mistake to appoint to the Commission those with inflexible or biased views. We should get that straight. It is known that the Australian Heritage Commission wants a seat on that Commission. It would be a disaster if one of those chaps or ladies--

TALK.START.PARA: —Women.
—Or ladies, Senator Vallentine. I would hope they were both. It would be a disaster if someone from the Australian Heritage Commission went on to the Resources Assessment Commission.
—Why so?

—I will tell Senator Sanders why it would be a disaster. Not only has Senator Sanders put them on the gravy train with all of their submissions, travelling expenses and staying at the Hilton Hotel or wherever they stay but also the Democrats will have a mole inside the Commission.
—Do you say that the Heritage Commission is a mole?
—It would be biased.
—Are the miners biased?
—The miners should not be on the Commission either. Senator Sanders should stop interrupting me. The Commission should be totally unbiased.
—Senator McGauran, you should address your remarks through the Chair.

—Certainly. The whole point is that the Commission should be utterly unbiased; it should be at arm's length from the mining and resource industries and the environmental groups. Neither should have a seat on the Commission. That has to be sorted out. We are unsure that that will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter that has already been mentioned is States rights. Certainly the States have not even been properly consulted on this Resource Assessment Commission. Their views have not been heard. The role of the Commission has not been properly explained to the States. So there is a concern, particularly when one thinks that the Resource Assessment Commission will be going into State areas, crossing the boundaries and touching on very sensitive areas, projects and State jurisdictions; and so the list goes on. The whole question of States rights is probably the most important point that the Senate committee should address.

Another point that should be addressed by the Senate committee is the confidentiality requirements. This is very important, especially for the resource companies. No resource company would wish to give a full account of the viability of a project if it knew that its competitors were able to view its case. There must be a degree of confidentiality by the Commission so as to build a confidence in its work. That is not too much to ask for. That is something that the Senate committee should look at. It would really add a great deal of strength to the Resource Assessment Commission, should it be established, and would allow the resource companies to come to the Resource Assessment Commission in full confidence. Otherwise we will witness a disintegration of the so-called environmental debate into opportunist politics and media spectacles, at a great loss to the development of our resources. It will, of course, have a continuing damaging effect upon our current account.

It is essential that Australia send a clear message and signal that resource developments will be given a fair hearing over the extremeness and senseless green arguments. That sort of self-indulgence of showy demonstrations that Senator Sanders is so often involved in--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the viewers biased?
—Quite frankly, Australia cannot afford those types of senseless and showy demonstrations any more. We are in a very serious economic situation in Australia.
—I don't recognise that?
—Senator Sanders does not recognise that.
—I do recognise that.

—I recognise the fact and the coalition recognises the fact. We have been trying to tell this Government and Senator Sanders's loonies for the past four to five years that Australia faces its most grave economic crisis. What we should be attempting to achieve is a balance between the development of our resources and the environmental issues. There are genuine concerns. No-one argues that. It is when the extremists take hold of the debate that I am concerned. Australia's standard of living is affected by such extremist attitudes.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has enormous reserves of wealth that need to be called upon in these times. The exploitation of these resources must be determined by careful assessment of the environment and economic considerations. For example, Australia has vast untapped uranium resources. Australia has almost one-third of the world's uranium supplies and deposits, yet it markets only 10 per cent onto the world market. On the other hand, Canada has 10 per cent of the world's reserves but almost one-third of the world market. The difference between Australia and Canada directly results from Australia's three-mine policy.

A rational uranium policy fostered by the deliberations of a group such as the Resource Assessment Commission could increase exports by at least $1.6 billion per year. The Government's Bureau of Mineral Resources has estimated that onshore oil explorations alone have the potential to unearth 200 million barrels in the next 10 years. At $20 per barrel that amounts to $4 billion, which is a highly significant figure in the context of the forecast of $5.5 billion annual bill for oil imports by 1998. The $5.5 billion annual oil import bill will be the result of a drop in Australia's crude oil self-sufficiency from 96 per cent in 1986 to only 28 per cent in 10 years time. Oil reserves are available in Australia to at least reduce, if not prevent, this blow-out. An innovative and efficient petroleum industry exists. What does not exist is a government prepared to take the tough decisions now that will benefit Australians for generations to come.

The list of untapped resources goes on. It includes coal of all types, $500 billion; mineral sands, $1,000m; copper, $32 billion; uranium, $36 billion, as I have already mentioned; gold, $20 billion of untapped resources; bauxite, $57 billion worth of untapped resources, and iron ore, $316 billion worth of untapped resources.

I recently served on the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts which was inquiring into the Kakadu National Park. The report entitled The Potential of the Kakadu National Park Region outlined the outstanding resource base of that region. It is well known to this Senate that the Jabiluka deposit contains a known uranium resource twice as large as Ranger. Its gold deposits are the highest grade of any Australian mine. Pancontinental Mining Ltd, which holds about 65 per cent interest in the joint venture seeking to develop the Jabiluka project, told the Committee that the gross value of resources was in excess of $20 billion. The Koongarra project also has some equally stunning figures which show the damage being done by not proceeding with these projects with due concern for the environment. We are missing out on valuable exports. If it is any consolation to this Government, it is missing out on some valuable taxes. I know how interested it is in taxes. It seems to be more interested in taxing the households of Australia than in taking advantage of our mineral resources and taxing some companies legitimately.

While I am still referring to Kakadu National Park, one of the most interesting statistics and lost opportunities is that the local Aboriginal people, by not developing these projects, are missing out on an estimated $256m.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want that grubby money.

—I cannot help but pick up on that interjection of Senator Sanders. He has not ceased interjecting. He enjoys interrupting the debate. I know I get on his quince. He said that they do not want that grubby money. Senator Sanders has just sought to put his grubby environmentalists onto the Commonwealth gravy train with his proposed amendments. Now he is saying that the Aboriginals do not want that grubby money. He should read the Committee's report to see what they have to say about that.
—They want their sacred sites.
—They want a fair deal.
—Order! Senator McGauran, ignore the interjections and address your remarks through the Chair.

—I know that one of my finest colleagues, Senator Crichton-Browne, is to follow me in this debate and I did not intend to talk for as long as I have. I have taken up more time because of the interjections. Senator Crichton-Browne served on the Committee. He was a fine contributor. He knows the area better than anyone else-better even than I do. I am certain he will pick up on some of Senator Sanders's wild, woolly, crazy and extremist interjections. I will handpass those points over to Senator Crichton-Browne. I hope Senator Sanders has the nerve to stick around. Senator Sanders is an absolute disgrace.
—Order! Senator McGauran, you will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw that remark, Mr Acting Deputy President. This is a serious issue. There are many other projects that the Resource Assessment Commission, an independent commission, could look at. It could look at the proposed pulp mills in Tasmania, at Grafton, and at Orbost in my State of Victoria. It could look at the Whale Point woodchip mill being developed in Tasmania by the Huon Forest Products organisation. It could look at the three stages of Kakadu and at the Kintyre uranium mine in Western Australia. It could look at the sandmining industry. It could conduct a general review of the Hunter Valley aluminium, coal, water and other resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Each year the balance of payments deficit adds over $10 billion to Australia's foreign debt, which is already over $100 billion. That is the reason we want a proper and balanced debate in this country. It is time for it. It is absolutely necessary to have this debate, otherwise Australians will face an ever decreasing standard of living. It is no joke any more. The Government had the chance, with the support of the coalition, with the support of the resource companies, and with the support of the more sensible environmental groups, to really balance this debate, to bring the parties together; but now that chance has been ruined, and sadly so. A properly composed commission could prevent some of the crazy political green groups from springing up. I want people to understand what I mean by that. I am talking about extremists. Every time I mention the crazy groups, I am talking about the extremists-those of political opportunism, those of showy demonstrations, those of 30-second television grabs, those who will never put anything on the table for sensible debate.

Everyone in this country is an environmentalist and a greenie, but it is time we stopped extremists grabbing the debate and dictating the agenda to this Government-dictating it through Senator Richardson. Thank goodness sense is shown by some in Cabinet from time to time. Minister Kerin is one such person, although I have not forgiven him for the wheat issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor have I.
—Senator Panizza has every right not to forgive him because wheat farmers in Western Australia will suffer more than farmers in any other State.
—Keep relevant.
—I am being relevant because I am getting to the issue of farmers, the people whom my Party, the National Party of Australia, represents.
—We represent them, too.

—But there is no party more aligned with the farmers than the National Party. That is our historical base; we cannot get away from that. There is no group of Australians more concerned about the environment than the farmers.
—Yes, we are with them all the time.

—Senator Panizza was once in the National Party, and so was Senator Vallentine. They are both good people and I invite them back. The farmers know the environment better than anyone else-certainly better than those people in the cities who have now taken hold of this debate. Why do people not understand that the farmers are the true environmentalists? Soil conservation is at the forefront of their day to day activities. They have to live with the weather. They have to work within the environment that they have chosen.
