Each farm-whether a wheat farm, a beef farm, a sheep farm or whatever-has a different environment; it virtually changes from farm gate to farm gate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sick and tired of the likes of Senator Sanders saying that the National Party knows nothing about environmental issues. We are the original environmentalists. We were the first to move legislation to protect the lands outside the cities. We cannot accept the city extremists taking hold of the environmental debate, pushing farmers around and saying that they do not know what we are on about. Farmers know more about the environment than do people in the cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we are with it all the time.

—That is right. I believe that the concept of the Resource Assessment Commission is to be supported but, sadly, the concept has gone off the rails because of the proposed Democrat amendments and the unwillingness of the Government to refer the matter to a Senate committee. I stress that a Senate committee would not delay the Bill beyond 1989; the legislation would be back here in the spring session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989, which comes to us as a result of the internecine machinations that have been taking place in the Australian Labor Party and more particularly in Cabinet in recent months, and as a result of particular and direct conflict between Senator Richardson and Mr Kerin and, to a lesser extent, Senator Cook. It is as a result of the conduct of this Government that the Bill is necessary in the first place. I observe that the major industry bodies have given their tacit but, I suggest, reluctant support to the legislation. They are of the view that the only way that the economic rationalists in the Government are going to start to win some of the arguments is to have the arguments on the table, to have them examined as objectively as possible by the Resource Assessment Commission, but that very much depends on the composition of the Commission-and I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, industry is gravely disturbed-perhaps from Australia's economic point of view-by the pyrrhic victories that Senator Richardson has been having to this point over the more sensible and economic rationalists in the Government. We have on one side those who are making hard-headed, brutal and crude decisions as to what is in the best interests of this Government as distinct from what is in the best interests of the country pitted against what one might describe as the political realists on the other side, those who are able to make measured judgments about what is good and necessary for this country.

That was highlighted in the Wesley Vale pulp mill debate. Some members of the Government understood the intrinsic virtue and the economic value of the Wesley Vale project but Senator Richardson and others were concerned primarily with votes and what was in the best interests of this Government. A fundamental economic base has been lost to Tasmania and to Australia as a result of the interference of the Federal Government, using a head of power that the founding fathers never conceived would be used by any government for that purpose.

Clearly, the Resource Assessment Commission will become the chief decision maker on all major resource development projects. It will be but another layer of bureaucracy imposed upon those who are trying to get on with the job of developing the abundance of natural resources with which God blessed our country. I rather wonder, for instance, whether the massive iron ore projects in the north-west of Western Australia would ever have got off the ground if in those days we had had a Resource Assessment Commission. It was only as a result of the diligence, efforts and dedication of the Western Australian Government at the time that those projects went ahead. They went ahead in spite of the Federal Government, which was saying that they could not and should not go ahead because Australia had limited iron ore reserves. Of course, once they got the go ahead and started to exploit and explore more they discovered, because of the incentive provided to them, the enormous reserves of iron ore in this country.

We have seen what this country offers to us even when the Government has limited control over the resource potential. We only have to look at the Kakadu region in the Northern Territory where the Federal Government has retained the management of those resources. We have seen the uranium industry in which Australia has 30 per cent of the world's known low cost uranium reserves but 10 per cent of the world market. We can compare that with Canada, which has 10 per cent of the world's known low cost uranium reserves but 30 per cent of the world market. Why is there that imbalance? It is because the Federal Government intervenes, imposes its will and seeks to make commercial decisions which are better made by industry at the coal face.

We have the Government telling us that we can sell uranium only at a floor price which is above the world market price. Inevitably, we miss contracts. We now find that Energy Resources of Australia Ltd has had inflicted upon it for the renewal of its uranium contracts floor prices that are above world prices. This means that potentially we will lose $1.1 billion worth of contracts, because this Government knows better than the marketplace! I fear that that will be the result for others now that the Government has taken the final quantum step of seeking to legitimise its involvement in resource areas and those areas that are fundamentally and historically State responsibilities.

I repeat the point made by Senator Michael Baume in his address when he referred to the heavy emphasis on the legalistic nature of this Commission. It is certainly no reflection on Judge Stewart when I say that I think he is an inappropriate appointee as Chairman. He has a fine background in those areas where he has experience and knowledge, but in no way does his experience relate to making judgments on and balancing the resource demand imperatives on the one hand and conservation considerations on the other. At the end of the day the composition of this Commission will be fundamental to its decisions, deliberations and determinations. I note that clause 11 determines-as is not unusual in these types of commissions:
The Commissioners shall be appointed by the Governor-General.

That simply means that they are Government appointments. If, in the scales of the deliberations, the Government has, as I suspect it will, a heavy emphasis in its appointment of commissioners on people who have a known concern for the environment, we can expect that the decisions will be distorted to that extent. I would have thought that under the circumstances somebody much more appropriate than a judge should head this Commission.
Clause 16 (1), when referring to resource matters being referred to the Commission, states:

Where the Commonwealth Government or a Commonwealth authority may, in the exercise of its powers, make a decision in relation to a resource matter, the Minister may, by written notice to the Chairperson, require the Commission to conduct an inquiry into the matter.

That clause states `may, in the exercise of its powers'. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, would know better than most that there is a difference between the exercise of powers which are visited upon it daily and the exercise of those powers which it seeks to pursue by redefining and reinterpreting the provisions of the Constitution, which this Government has done over the last six years.

Section 51 of the Constitution is a good example. The external affairs power was never intended, never imagined and never proposed to relate to conservation and the environment. How could our Founding Fathers, when they were drafting those words, have ever imagined that an external affairs power could be used by a government in the future to take unto itself residual powers previously intended for the States in respect of conservation? So, when the Government talks about `in the exercise of its powers', it is really talking about powers by pursuit-powers that it has taken unto itself as a result of its own endeavours and extending the Constitution to the very limit.

My other concern in terms of logistical problems with the Commission is that there will be another gap between companies looking at projects and ultimately being able to make decisions. I am reminded of the Western Mining Corporation's often repeated example of Kambalda, where I think two State government agencies were required to grant approval for the mining of nickel. I think that in the State Government alone about 35 agencies are now required to give approval before a project can commence. Operators will now have imposed upon them the Resource Assessment Commission, which no doubt will be directed to give consideration to and make deliberations in respect of all major resource projects. Because of the inevitable backlog of work, there will be a considerable delay between the time a company decides to commence a project and when approval is given to it.
I am absolutely stunned when I see the Australian Democrats amendment that the Government has agreed to. It is absolutely breathtaking in its audacity. In part, it states:
(3) If the Chairperson considers it appropriate, a person who gives evidence to, or produces documents at, an inquiry may be:
(a) paid such remuneration as is prescribed for the performance of work involved in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents . . .
Can honourable senators believe it? It continues:
or (b) reimbursed such expenses, or compensated for such losses, as were reasonably incurred in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents;
or both.

That is an open cheque for every looney organisation in this country to spend a fortune constructing their arguments against the exploitation and development of every single project in Australia at any given time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will create a whole new profession.

—It will. A whole new industry will spring up, a whole new industry of these out of work, won't work types, running around the country at taxpayers' expense spending enormous amounts of taxpayers' money in an unlimited way, doing research into whether or not projects ought to be allowed. One can imagine the industry that will spring up. Every time a project is about to get off the drawing board, whether for uranium, oil, bauxite or gold, there will be pressure on the Federal Government through this minority, this lobby group-albeit vocal, effective and articulate-upon the Resource Assessment Commission to take it as a term of reference. At every turn the whims and the wishes of these groups will be accommodated by this Government as they have been in the past. The Government has turned itself inside out to attract their vote. Once a term of reference is given to the Commission, all these groups will immediately get on to these projects, studying and examining them, developing arguments in a subjective fashion-to which we have all become accustomed-to persuade the Commission that the project ought not to go ahead for some environmental reason.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has agreed to this amendment. I see Senator Sanders sitting over there smiling and nodding approval at the acquiescence of the Government to this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he will get one of the jobs?

—I think Senator Sanders has been writing the terms of reference for his next career. When we had before us the resource rental tax legislation the Democrats voted with the Opposition against the legislation-for quite different reasons. Then Senator Richardson went to the Democrats-Senator Sanders, to wit-and said `What will it cost us to get our legislation through?'. Senator Sanders said `What about $5m to study and examine the potential for wind-driven energy resources?'. We are spending $5m of taxpayers' money trying to develop windmills to generate electricity in this country. That was the price of getting the Government's resource rental tax legislation through-bought for a dollar; politically paid off.
—Senator Button is ashamed of that.
—I do not know about that. I doubt it. Senator Button is able to accommodate all these agreements.
—But he is embarrassed about it.
—I should hope that Senator Button is embarrassed about it. I would be disappointed if he were not; but I have had many disappointments from Senator Button over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: The last matter I want to touch upon is the question of States rights. Perhaps I am a quaint, anachronistic relic of the past by concerning myself--

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—Senator Button agrees with that. Perhaps because I am concerned with the matter of States rights, State responsibilities, the devolution of power and the transfer of decision-making back to the people, I am an anachronism and a relic of a bygone era. But I say to Senator Button that the people of China are finding out that people power has virtue. This Government has finally made the quantum leap. It has finally discarded the pretence of being virginal. It has now plunged headlong into areas that, as I say, historically, intrinsically and inherently, have been intended for the States and were written into the Constitution in those clear and precise terms. The Government has stopped pretending. The facade has gone. The curtain has gone up. It no longer pretends that it has tripped over a head of power that requires it to consider these matters. Government members are now saying `We will legislate to formalise our interference in State matters'.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day it begs the question. We know where Mr Hayden stood in respect of States rights; presumably he still does, although he is not able to exercise a view about it. We know where the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, stands in respect of States rights. We know where the Australian Democrats stand in respect of States rights. Essentially, they all reflect the view of this Government-that is, that we ought not to have State governments, that the federal system ought to be abolished, that all power ought to be centralised in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —They came a gutser on that at the referendum.

—This Government, in the face of overwhelming opposition, as we are seeing in the polls, is persisting in going down the road of economic disaster to the detriment of itself and to the agony of the country. Only the polls can turn the Government ignominiously out of office and keep it out forever. In the meantime we are afflicted with the Government.
—They just might not turn you in, though, Senator. That is your problem.

—I do not believe that States rights is simply a slogan. There is something fundamental and human about the belief in the devolution of power and the transfer of power nearest to the people to ensure that decision making is made and implemented in areas where it is most effective. This Government has adequately demonstrated what happens when we have a centralised decision making process by a government in Canberra, insulated, isolated and removed from the daily affairs of men. It is inevitable that those from Victoria, such as Senator Button, and those from New South Wales will not understand the subtlety of State responsibilities because those two States combined have more members in the House of Representatives from outer metropolitan Melbourne and Sydney alone than the total representation of the less populous States. So it is natural that they are insensitive to the concerns of people from the less populous and more remote States.

SPEECH.PARA: We see this Bill, which, sadly, is going through in such a short time, as redefining and reshaping State and Federal responsibilities. The Bill before us deals exclusively with Australia's resources in whatever form they might be. The Bill sets up a commission to examine resources and competing interests, to examine whether exploitation of those resources collectively or individually is the best economic decision for Australia. The Bill has been set up to weigh all those things-if one is an altruist. The Bill does not once mention States or State governments. It does not accept, acknowledge or respect the sovereign responsibilities of the States. There is no provision in the Bill that requires cooperation or consultation with the States. The Bill enshrines for the Federal Government all responsibility for all decisions regarding the examination, development and exploitation of Australia's resources. I find it absolutely stunning that this Government has become so remote, so aloof, so arrogant and so detached from reality that it no longer even has a pretence or a facade of purporting to cooperate with the States. It no longer even acknowledges or recognises their rights.

As a lawyer, Senator Button would know that the Constitution, in terms of its separa- tion of powers, quite explicitly-not implicitly-provides that the resources and the resource potential of each of the States are exclusively a right for and responsibility of the States. There is no provision in the Constitution for any second-guessing or determination in respect of any matters affecting the resources of the States. But this Federal Government is using High Court decisions-the decision in the dams case is the benchmark, the watershed, in respect of the matter-to give it powers to interfere. As I say, this legislation is born out of the imbroglio that this Government has got itself into in terms of its domestic, in-house politics, the competing and conflicting debate that goes on regularly between the economic rationalists like Mr Kerin compared with the political hardheads like Senator Richardson. We now have before us this piece of legislation to resolve a domestic problem. It is not derived, determined or arrived at for the good of Australia, for the good of the economy or for the good of its people. It is arrived at as a mechanism, as a source or as a form of settling a dispute. It is what one might call a makarrata between--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook and Senator Richardson.

—Between Senator Cook and Senator Richardson and Mr Kerin on Senator Cook's side. It is not a piece of legislation that is designed to enhance the well-being and welfare of ordinary Australians. It is a crude and blatant instrument to find some peace between the warring factions of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The various industries-the mining industry, the oil industry and the farming industry-have all inextricably been sucked into this debate. So far, they have been doing pretty badly. Senator Richardson has been winning most of the battles. At the end of the day, looking at where the votes are, it is the noisy, radical minority groups that have been winning the battles and losing the war for Australia. The industry has lobbied me, and presumably most of my colleagues, to support this Bill, not because it wants it, not because it thinks it has any intrinsic virtue and not because it thinks it is in its best interests, but simply because for the moment it is its best bet. At least it believes that it will be able to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why aren't you supporting it then if they have lobbied you?

—I am sorry I am so obviously inarticulate. I have spent 25 minutes explaining why I am opposed to it. I am setting out for the benefit of the Senate why, as they say in the vernacular these days, the industry is between a rock and a hard place. The reason the industry is supporting the Commission is that it judges that, at least if there is a commission, it has got half a chance of having its argument heard. It perhaps has some forlorn hope-I do not know; I hope not-that if a commission is set up it will be able to put its arguments up with equal weight, force and influence to that of the environmentalists who right now, because of the votes they carry in their bags, are winning all the battles. The industry judges that with this Commission it will all be out on the table. It will be heard in equal measure with the conservation lobby. At the end of the day, the economic rationalists in the Government hope that the Commission will deliver unto them logical and reasonable arguments in support of these projects which, so far, have been falling over the edge in the desperate scramble and in the dying days of this failed Government, which hopes it is going to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has prostituted Australia's resources, the welfare and the best interests of this country in a desperate last grab to survive in office. That is why I suspect that at the end of the day we will end up with a half Senate election so that the Government can postpone the election day until November 1990. I was going to say that the Government hopes to God that something will turn up, but it cannot do that because we have a Prime Minister who is an atheist. He hopes to somebody that something is going to turn up, that something around the corner will come along and that something will happen to the Opposition. At the end of the day, we are all afflicted with the Resource Assessment Commission Bill. We are moving that it should be sent to a committee to give that committee the opportunity to consider a number of matters which we believe go to the heart of our concerns about the Bill. We have two amendments that Senator Austin Lewis will be moving in the committee stage. One touches upon the States rights responsibilities--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to discuss the need for a national approach to major, complex and contentious resource use issues, as most resource issues do not observe State borders and would benefit from a unified approach to management, which is the stated intent of the Resource Assessment Commission Bill. Therefore, I will not be supporting the amendments to be moved by the Opposition. I think the community would also welcome a balanced approach to resource management. It would also welcome access to resource information currently held by industry, which would allow members of the public to make more informed decisions about public resources. Senator Lewis would have this information enshrined in commercial in-confidence provisions and so perpetuate the biased basis of resource decisions. That is a problem that we have had in the past. That needs to be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a rising wave of support in the community for a change in economic direction away from unnecessary environmental degradation for the quick buck and towards more sustainable forms of economic activity. The other measures announced in November last year in concert with this Bill, regarding increased resources for the Australian Heritage Commission and establishing new consultative processes with conservation and industry groups, are commendable steps towards redressing this imbalance.

The purpose of the Resource Assessment Commission Bill, stated by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, in his second reading speech, is to inquire into, and report on, the environmental, cultural, social, industry, economic or other aspects of resources and their uses. The Minister went on to say that the Commission would be expected to consider how resources may be used at present or in the future, looking at the kinds of values that individuals or groups in the community place on the resource or on the uses that can be made of it, including who will gain and who will lose in both material and non-material ways. Minister Kerin was reported in the Australian on 14 February to say that the investment climate for forestry had never looked better, thanks to, among other things, the proposed Resource Assessment Commission (RAC). It is not surprising, then, that industry groups have supported the proposed Commission and that conservationists are wary about its real purpose-a creation, as it is, of the development orientated Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

The utilitarian view of the environment is reflected in the definitions adopted in the Bill. For example, the word `sustainable' is not applied in relation to the definition of development. Instead, it is included in the definition of `conservation' as being `. . . the greatest sustainable benefit to present generations while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations . . .' The definition of conservation would have been improved if it went beyond strictly human use of the environment and made specific reference to the maintenance of genetic diversity in species and ecosystems. For as long as the attitude persists that the elements of the natural environment have value only in so far as they can be used by humans, there is a danger that we will continue to use them and lose them from under our noses.

The three policy principles which would guide the Commission in resolving competing resource use claims also raise concerns about the lack of ecologically based principles. The amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats address this imbalance and therefore should be supported. In the first guiding principle we are told that there should be an integrated approach to conservation and development. In an ideal sense, a balance sounds great. What is out of balance and has been out of balance since the arrival of white settlers in this country is our attitude to and treatment of the natural environment. Soil erosion figures of 90 million tonnes per annum, native species losses and dwindling native forests provide ample testimony to that. States rights have not been successful in redressing these problems. A national approach is absolutely essential.

How will the balance be restored through the Resource Assessment Commission? In the original Bill commissioners would have been appointed by two industry advocate groups: the Industries Assistance Commission and the Australian Science and Technology Council. Neither agency is known for its expertise in conservation matters. Such structural bias does not abide by the first principle of an integrated approach to conservation and development. The amendments to include the Australian Heritage Commission, which is known for its expertise in conservation matters, go some way to restore a semblance of balance to the nominating committee, though it is still not exactly even Steven. Here I must make mention of Senator McGauran's derogatory remarks about the Australian Heritage Commission. They cannot go unchallenged. He referred to the Commission as a mole as part of the RAC. Maybe that is not such an insult after all because moles, with their burrowing under the soil and their constant turning over and aeration of the soil, certainly understand the notion of sustainability, even though it is not understood by Senator Lewis, by his own admission.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very good agriculturalists.

—Exactly. So maybe to call the Australian Heritage Commission a mole was not such an insult as Senator McGauran intended. Senator McGauran's comments about extremist greenies also show how out of touch he is with mainstream thinking in the Australian community at the moment. Conservationists are no longer seen as extremists. The things that have been said by the conservation movement for many years are now being accepted as mainstream community views. To call people who are concerned about the long term view of Australia's environment and the global environment extremists shows just how out of touch with current thinking some members of the Opposition are.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the most serious reservation about the integration principle is that it could be used to impose an integrated mix of conservation and development on those few areas reserved for the primary purpose of conservation-our national parks and nature reserves. This apprehension also applies to the third guiding principle of the proposed Resource Assessment Commission, that of providing for uses additional to the primary resource use to take place concurrently or sequentially. Concurrent use is commonly know as multiple use. The concept of multiple use has been abused in the past and is eagerly adopted by the mining industry to legitimise mining in areas of high conservation value. According to an article by John R. Burton published by the Australian Mining Industry Council, `multiple use invariably involves a trade-off between competitive uses and the working out of a compromise mix of uses'.

We know from history and the current orientation of most government ministries, including that of Primary Industries and Energy, that conservation rates a very low second in the majority of competitions for land use because it does not deliver an immediate return in the form of a fistful of dollars. The operation of the Resource Assessment Commission will be watched very carefully in this regard. Senator McGauran's comments reveal an attitude which is becoming obsolete in the community, that is, of an economy driven by dollars being ahead of all other considerations, particularly environmental considerations. That line of thinking does not count the cost of the environmental clean-ups that are necessary after many developments which wreak havoc with the environment. We have only to look at soil degradation in that regard. That example alone proves the point that the economy approach, driven by a dollar reward as the first and primary consideration, is very expensive in the long run. That has to be acknowledged. It is too expensive to take a dollars first attitude any longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I feel that Senator Vallentine has been misrepresenting the facts of the address I gave to the House. In no way did I indicate that I was driven by the dollar only. I believe that I quite clearly stated that there was a balanced approach to be taken. She has utterly misrepresented my position.
—Order! That is not a point of order. You will have an opportunity to make a personal explanation if you feel you have been misrepresented.

—Another issue very clearly raised by Senator McGauran and Senator Crichton-Browne was that of uranium mining. That used to be a classic case of, `If there is a dollar in it, let us do it'. It is no longer so clearly the case now because the markets are in jeopardy. However, it is still the exploitative approach and that is what I am challenging. Uranium mining is totally environmentally unacceptable. I do not believe that an expansion of the mining industry in Australia will be allowed, because public opinion now is so firmly against the expansion of that industry which is seen to be environmentally very damaging. Forget about the possible use of uranium in dangerous nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons; look at the end result of uranium mining-the production of the most toxic kind of radioactive leftovers known to humanity. It is environmentally totally unacceptable. For people still to push uranium mining reveals their total lack of understanding of current thinking about environmental issues.
—What about coal?

—Has Senator McGauran not heard about the greenhouse effect? Has he not heard that greenhouse gases are spewed into the atmosphere by coal fired power stations? I must say that he is not the only one who has not made that connection. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber, also made the mistake of not acknowledging that connection of coal fired power stations having an impact on the greenhouse effect globally when I asked him a question about the proposed Mount Lesueur coal project in Western Australia. He said it was a matter for the States to look at, which again points up the necessity for this Resource Assessment Commission. The States are not responsible in making decisions about the global environment if they are driven by economic interests very close to home which do not take into account enough of the total and long term effect of the projects under consideration. That exploitative model must stop. If members of the Opposition have not yet tumbled to the fact that the people of Australia-indeed, of the globe-no longer accept the exploitative model, they relegate themselves to the Opposition benches for a very long time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned that the RAC will be another layer of bureaucracy to stop people from getting on with the job. He is talking about the job of exploiting our resources. Wise management is absolutely essential. That is what the Commission is about: looking at possible projects; having an overall view of what the resources are; and considering the wise management of those resources.

Senator Crichton-Browne said that the legislation is not good for Australia; it is not designed to enhance our economy or the well-being of the people of Australia. These kinds of comments reveal, as has often been said, that politicians are often the last to pick up on changes in community attitudes. Perhaps it is because politicians far too often remove themselves from the thinking of people in the community. Senator Crichton-Browne called himself an anachronism. I am not saying anything about him that he has not said about himself. He revealed that his attitudes are totally illogical and that he is misreading the current climate of opinion in the community.

It is true that various industries support the Commission because they understand the reality of the need to negotiate about resource management better than the coalition does. The industries realise that no longer can they have it all their own way, which has been the situation in the past.

My final comment is in regard to public participation in decisions affecting public resources and the opportunities for necessary input into Resource Assessment Commission inquiries by groups representing the conservation interests of the community. These have been improved. They need to be very carefully watched. For public participation to have any real meaning, it must be facilitated early in the process when the terms of reference for inquiries are being determined. Otherwise community concerns about resource use and its long term implications will be too easily dismissed as being outside the official terms of reference, as they so often are in specific project impact assessments. I am disappointed that this is not included in the amendments accepted by the Government. It is at that early stage that community input is absolutely vital.

Overall the process embodied in the Resource Assessment Commission Bill-that of a more balanced approach to resource use in this country-will provide a more focused approach to problems such as land degradation, native vegetation retention, energy production and native species loss. I support the Bill and the amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats because I believe that, if managed wisely with a long view of development projects and their effects on the environment, the Resource Assessment Commission will begin to address seriously the issue of sustainability which is fundamental to our survival.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In replying to the second reading addresses of honourable senators, I do not wish to take up much time of the Senate other than to reassert that we are debating the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989. It is a Bill the Government has brought forward with widespread support of the community and industry organisations. It is a Bill that is based on our view of what the national conservation strategy for Australia requires governments to do. It is a Bill consistent with the report of the Brundtland Commission, Our common future, and the need to balance environmental aspirations of the community with those of the economic and developmental sectors. The purpose of the Bill is to provide an information base which makes the contending arguments clear, understandable and settled as far as they can be so that there is a platform for good decision making by government and so that good decision making can concentrate on finding win-win outcomes; wins for the environment and wins for the economic well-being of the community. It is desirable that, where it is in the public interest, those decisions be constructed so that both sides benefit. Where those outcomes cannot be constructed in that way, governments have to make decisions. It is important that they make decisions based on the widest canvassing of arguments, the widest understanding of contending points of view and a clear common understanding of the issues. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now urgent to pass this legislation because, increasingly these days and more so in the future, governments will be judged in terms of their performance in office not only on how they handle economic management but also on how they handle development and environmental issues. That will be a hallmark of good judgment and good government in future. It is important that we equip ourselves with the instruments to conduct government in that way from now on, urgently. Thus, I reject the coalition motion to refer this matter to a committee. I indicate that the Government will be supporting the amendments to be moved by the Australian Democrats to strengthen the Bill but rejecting those to be moved by the Opposition.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 13-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 14 (Selection of special Commissioners).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, clause 14, line 5, paragraph (b), insert ``the Australian Heritage Commission,'' after ``of''.

I move this amendment for the reason, as I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate, that the Australian Heritage Commission is concerned with the environment and should have an input into the system. While I am on my feet, I point out that some of the speakers in the second reading debate mentioned concern over the insulation of the Government from the public pressure in the Resource Assessment Commission Bill. This worried the Australian Democrats. I believe that the Government has a responsibility to make decisions itself. Often governments of whatever political stripe will send something to a commission or a committee to avoid making responsible decisions. This was a worry with this Commission, but I think on balance the public-and the mining industry for that matter-will still have input into the system.

I think the system can be made to work. It still requires a public scrutiny, but everything any government does requires the input of the people. The Australian Democrats and, I think, the environmental movement are willing to let the facts speak for themselves. We are not worried about what the minerals industry or the woodchipping industry can come up with in terms of information. We believe that when the facts are evaluated in a dispassionate light, justice will prevail. We are not afraid of that.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 15 agreed to.
Clause 16 (Reference of resource matter to Commission).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move Opposition amendment No. 1:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, after subclause 16 (1), insert the following new subclause:

``(1a) Before the Minister requires the Commission to conduct an inquiry under subsection (1), the Minister is to consult with the Government of each State or Territory that may be affected by the inquiry.''.

This is a very simple and clear amendment. It is obvious that, in the assessment of resources of this nation, the States play a sovereign role. The Constitution provides that the States shall have their responsibilities and obligations and their rights. The Resource Assessment Commission Bill ignores those rights and responsibilities. All we are saying to the Government in this amendment is that the Minister for Resources should consult. We are not saying that the Minister should obtain the agreement of the government but simply that he should consult with the government of each State or Territory that may be affected before requiring the Commission to conduct an inquiry. It is a simple amendment and I put it to the Senate that it should be accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated in my speech in the second reading debate, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting this type of amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept this amendment. What Senator Lewis has said about the need for consultation is a fair point, but the Government believes that such consultation would be conducted, where appropriate, in any case, and that there is no need to put such a provision in the Bill. The Commission is not a body which need create anxiety or worry in terms of State constitutional rights. I suspect that the reason we are being asked to enshrine in legislation a provision compelling consultation on all references is a worry that somehow or other this may be an intrusion by the Commonwealth into the constitutional domain of the States. The body that I could draw a parallel with is the Industries Assistance Commission. To the best of my knowledge, that body conducts inquiries into matters which affect the economic well-being of Australian industry, and thus it affects industry in the various States. But in framing references to the IAC, the Government is not required, as I understand the Industries Assistance Commission Act, to consult the States. We are looking at a national industry view. The sorts of references that the Government contemplates would be referred to this Commission are those that will look, by and large, at a national perspective and thus, in the normal course, would run across the margins of States, involve several States or Territories and not be likely to be merely a focus of a particular State or part of a particular State on which States would want, therefore, to jealously guard their rights to affect any reference.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the point about consultation, by and large, is fair. This Government has a good record on consultation. It is not necessary to go to the extent of putting special provisions for it in the legislation. Indeed, if the motivation for wanting to do that is a widespread fear-to put it in the terms in which it is flung back at us-of a grab from Canberra for national control over State rights, I think that is a misplaced fear in the circumstances. The model, after all, is close to that of the IAC, and that working model has been effective.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 11.55 a.m. under sessional order I shall report to the Senate.
