Is it correct that a spouse representative attended meetings of the Defence Housing Authority as an observer from January 1988 until the legislation was amended on 24 November 1988? Is it correct that no appointment of a spouse representative has been made to the Board of the Authority since the legislation was passed in November 1988? What is the justification for this? Does this mean that there have been no voting rights for a spouse representative on the Board of the Defence Housing Authority from its inception in January 1988 until now? When will a spouse representative be appointed to the Board? Will such a spouse representative be given travel funding by the Government or the Authority to maintain contact with the Defence Force families he or she represents around Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information in my brief here on the matters which Senator Newman has raised. I shall seek information and let the honourable senator know as soon as I can.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Has he seen the claims made yesterday by the Prime Minister that it was ignorant to indicate that Australia's debt should be spoken about in any sense as being a debt related to each individual Australian man, woman and child? Does the Minister recall his own comments in the Senate on 29 May to precisely the same effect that somehow it was wrong to characterise debt as being related to each individual Australian? I ask the Minister whether he recalls the Prime Minister's election policy speech launch of 23 June 1987 in which the Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: I told you of the disastrous drop in the prices of our exports-a collapse in world trade that has now cost every Australian family $2,000.

Can the Minister indicate why it is ignorant to talk about Australia's debt in terms of the debt owed by every man, woman and child, whereas the Prime Minister is able to talk about the collapse in world trade having cost every Australian family $2,000? Where is the consistency in this approach or is it simply that the Prime Minister's standards are entirely variable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall all the comments and so on that have been put to me in the question but I accept them at their face value. The remarks made about characterising Australia's debt as being a personal debt for each man, woman and child in Australia have always been seen as extremely simplistic and, if you like, a politically motivated view of the situation. That is what can honestly be said about it.

ANSWER.PARA: On the more general issue: Senator Puplick would realise that all the statements made in June 1987 or, for that matter, in June or August 1988 by political commentators, economists, government spokesmen and indeed opposition spokesmen indicated a misunderstanding of the level of growth in the Australian economy, and the consequent problems which have flowed from that were not foreseen at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister noted an account in yesterday's edition of the Australian of the Emperor of Japan buying a consignment of Tasmanian sheep to improve the bloodlines of his imperial flock? Does this royal endorsement open an opportunity for the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) to upgrade its promotion of our lamb in a bid to increase exports to Japan over the current level of 18 million a year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noticed in yesterday's Australian under the heading `Tasmanian lamb gets imperial imprimatur' an article which said that His Imperial Highness, the Emperor of Japan, was purchasing lambs from Tasmania, the finest Suffolk sheep in the world, to improve the bloodlines of the royal flock. I must say I agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Jones that the selection of Australian sheep for this purpose only serves to emphasise the quality of the product available from Australia.
—Tasmanian sheep.

—I will pick up the interjection by my colleague from Tasmania Senator Tate who said that I should say `Tasmanian'. I must say that I acknowledge his enthusiasm for his own State but I recognise that Tasmania is part of Australia and, therefore, I will say that it is Australian sheep that the Emperor has selected.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn now to the second part of the question from Senator Jones. The central problem facing the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation in promoting Australian lamb in Japan is that it has a somewhat exotic image. The AMLC is attempting to address the problem through a comprehensive promotional campaign involving restaurant and supermarket promotions, public relations activities, trade activities, promotions along the lines of the beef shortcuts advertisements that we see on television and the provision of recipes and other cooking advice to Japanese householders on how they should experience obviously the succulent delicacies of Australian lamb Japanese style.

The purchase of Australian sheep, sourced from Tasmania, by the Emperor serves to highlight the standards of Australian sheep and Australian sheep meat in Japanese eyes and thus is a recognition of the standards we have achieved and is beneficial to our broad image in Japan. But it is the type of promotional campaign that the AMLC is running that will ultimately mean that more Australian sheep meat turns up in Japanese pots in the future. Our trade balance will improve as a result. Nonetheless I acknowledge the Emperor's discernment in selecting Tasmanian sourced Australian sheep.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the Minister to the decision last week of a Perth magistrate to suppress the publication of evidence given by a former solicitor for Rothwells Ltd, Mr Leon Musca. Is it a fact that Mr Musca did not make a statement to the investigation by the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) into the Rothwells debacle and that his evidence is his first formal comment on the matters that were the subject of that investigation and the report which was tabled in this Parliament? Does the Minister agree that Mr Musca's evidence will clearly be of great interest to the NCSC? Has the Commission had access to that evidence? If not, can and will it seek such access?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that they were committal proceedings.
—It seems to be an application by the Corporate Affairs Commission.

—In some proceedings in the Magistrates Court in Perth, the magistrate has made a decision to suppress the publication of evidence beyond the confines of the court. I have no comment to make on that decision by the magistrate.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with Senator Chaney that quite obviously any matter to do with the collapse of Rothwells Ltd is a matter of concern not only to the immediate parties but also to a wider community of interest both in Western Australia and Australia-wide. Having not been informed of the matter, I will find out whether the National Companies and Securities Commission can in some way make itself aware of the proceedings and their content before the magistrate. I will take up that matter and seek a response. Perhaps I could inform Senator Chaney privately if the Senate is up before I get a response.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TECHNICAL AND FURTHER EDUCATION: ENROLMENT STATISTICS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to a report that technical and further education (TAFE) enrolment statistics at one Queensland campus had been falsified, resulting in seven teachers being employed to perform the work of three. The same report notes that at another campus, the total student time was overstated by 48,000 hours. In view of the substantial financial contribution made by the Federal Government to TAFE capital funding and the recurrent funding provided for specific purposes, will the Minister have investigations made to determine whether any Federal funds were affected by these fraudulent activities?

—I have seen the report. Assuming it is fundamentally accurate, it is not entirely clear whether the fraud was being perpetrated in a centralised way by the State Government or whether it was decentralised fraud being perpetrated by one or more TAFE colleges. The enrolment statistics for TAFE colleges are not supplied directly to the Federal Government by the colleges. In the case of Queensland-and I think in the case of all the other States-the statistics are supplied to the Commonwealth Government by the Queensland Department of Employment, Vocational Education and Training. Of course the Commonwealth will be taking this issue up with that Queensland State Department. Commonwealth TAFE grants, however, are not provided on a per capita basis and are supplementary to the State's own funding. However, grants to the States for TAFE are made available under the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Act 1989. Under the accountability provisions of the legislation, States are required to provide audited statements of expenditure certifying that the grants were expended for the purpose for which they were given. Therefore, the Queensland Department will be obliged under that condition to supply the Commonwealth with a report on the matter. One would hope that it will be a truthful and accurate report, although perhaps some people might not be entirely confident that that condition will be met.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of the Public Accounts Committee from the Legislative Assembly of Sabah, led by the Hon. James Vitales. On behalf of all senators I welcome them to the Senate and trust that their visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it not a fact that the depth of our economic crisis and the toughness and duration of the measures needed to get us out of the mess are much more serious than the Australian public yet seems to realise? Is not the only economic weapon the Government has left itself-high interest rates-a very blunt instrument, with very undesirable side effects in harming individuals, discouraging essential investment and, by keeping the Australian dollar artificially high, hurting our exporters and import replacers? Is it not obvious to any dispassionate observer that we must use much tougher tax and wage policies and reductions in government expenditure to restrain demand until we can improve productivity sufficiently to justify our higher standard of living, and that we urgently need a proper consumption tax to encourage savings? Is not the problem for this Government-and indeed for any government-the fear of voter reaction to difficult measures, not fully understood, particularly with an election imminent? In view of the gravity of the national economic crisis, will the Government approach the Opposition with a view to working out a joint national policy of economic recovery? Can we afford yet another year of drift?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Hamer himself would recognise that the last part of his question is a bit unrealistic. However, if it were a real possibility-and I do not believe it is-I think that the views of people such as Dr Hewson and Senator Stone would be worth considering, but I do not think the views of the Leader of the Opposition, for example, would be worth listening to. That would be one problem even if it were a realistic option, which it is not. I was asked whether the public realises the gravity of the economic situation. The answer requires a subjective judgment.
—What about John Howard?

—Senator Button has reminded me that John Howard might be worth listening to if the Government were looking for ideas and suggestions on economic policy from the Opposition. My own subjective judgment, which is the same as Senator Hamer's, is that the public does not realise the situation fully. I have been asked whether the only economic weapon the Government is using is a tight monetary policy. The answer to that is no; it is not the only weapon. We will be continuing with a fiscal policy which would have previously been regarded in Australia as being unbelievably tight. We have a Budget surplus this year of close to 2 per cent of gross domestic product and a Budget surplus next year of about the same size-possibly a bit lower as a proportion of gross domestic product-and a public sector borrowing requirement figure of about one per cent of GDP negative.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not want to go into any great detail on the question of a consumption tax, but I think the arguments about the mix of the tax system should stand on their own merits or demerits, and that those people who believe that changing a tax mix from income taxes towards consumption taxes will significantly alter behaviour are wrong. An increase in consumption taxes, accompanied by a commensurate reduction in income taxes, would, at least on average, mean that the same amount of income is available to purchase the goods that people believe they need or want. While it would not affect all groups equally, it is self-delusion to believe that savings behaviour would be markedly changed by a shift in the composition of taxes from income taxes to consumption taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Senator Walsh, in answering that part of the question which related to fiscal policy, compared the present situation with the past. Surely what he should be doing is comparing the present fiscal policy with the present problems. Is it his contention that present fiscal policy is tough enough for our present economic problems?

—As I have said before, one of the problems with attempting to make judgments about the direction in which economic policy should be going is that nobody knows for sure where we are now because of the inevitable lag between what is happening in the real world and the statistical cataloguing of it. If we apply that to the present situation, we will see that monetary policy has been very tight, but nobody knows at the moment the extent to which that has affected what is going on in the economy. We will not know some aspects of that for a very long time. In three or four months time we will have some idea. We have to make judgments about what monetary policy has already done but is not yet apparent.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of and concerned about the fearful fire blight disease which may or may not have come from New Zealand? Is he aware of the effect that disease may have on fruit such as apple, pear and the nashi fruit.
—And kiwi fruit?

—It does not affect the kiwi fruit. Has concern been expressed by the growers of Shepparton, including Mr Colin Bragg? Has the Waterside Workers Federation in Melbourne also expressed concern in support of the growers, through Mr Jim Beggs? What does the Government intend to do in the light of the concern about the disease?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the questions are yes, yes and yes. Let me now explain. I am aware of fire blight. Fire blight is a bacterium which infects the blossom of fruit trees of the apple or pear variety, leading to twig dieback, ultimately trunk or branch dieback and, in extreme cases, the death of the tree and thus the wiping out of it as fruit bearing growth. The fruits that it affects are mostly pears, although Senator Cooney has referred to nashi fruit. Nashi fruit is a cross between apples and pears. It affects that fruit as well as ornamental trees based on the family of apples and pears or their crosses. It is true that the farmers of Shepparton have expressed concern. In fact, a delegation of them is coming to see me today. It is also true that the President of the Waterside Workers Federation in Port Melbourne, Jim Beggs, has today contacted my office to express support for the farmers' delegation.

ANSWER.PARA: The origin of these concerns is that recently a consignment of 248 boxes of nashi fruit-the apple-pear cross-was imported from New Zealand and was inadvertently released on the Australian market for sale. I understand that the consignment was admitted after inspectors of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture had cleared it. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service believed that there may have been an infection of fire blight and at least one-fifth of the consignment was retrieved. On a piece by piece basis, 200 fruits have been examined.

From news just to hand, I understand that the infection is not a fire blight infection but some other bacterium. More work is being done on that. As a consequence of this shipment of contaminated fruit-contaminated by whatever organism-having got into Australia and because of the threat that poses to the Australian apple and pear industry, the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and my Department, in the form of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, are conducting a re-examination of entry procedures and approvals so that there will not be a repetition of this event. I understand that the delegation referred to by Senator Cooney, which is supported by the Waterside Workers Federation, is wanting to discuss those procedures so that it can be assured that there will not be a recurrence of this event.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It also refers to the suppression by a Perth magistrate last week of the evidence of former Rothwells Ltd solicitor, Mr Leon Musca. Is the Minister aware that counsel for media organisations challenging the suppression order has told the Supreme Court that Mr Musca's evidence should be released because it raises questions about the frankness and credibility of Premier Dowding concerning his role in this matter? Does the Minister agree that the people of Western Australia have a right to know the full story of the involvement of their Premier and possibly other senior Ministers in the Rothwells scandal? Does he further agree that it should be possible to make public, as was done with the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) Rothwells report, a version of the Musca evidence which would not prejudice the outcome of the legal proceedings pending against Mr Tony Lloyd, Mr Kevin Edwards and Mr John Hilton? Does the Federal Attorney-General have any authority in this matter? If so, will the Minister ask the Attorney to intervene in support of disclosure of non-prejudicial facts when the challenge to the suppression order comes before the court again next week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated that I have no personal knowledge of these matters, either by way of media reports or even less by way of any official publication of the proceedings to which Senator Knowles apparently refers, namely, submissions made to the court concerning the suppression order. I do not know whether that is speculation by the media or an unauthorised report by the media, which perhaps falls outside the terms of the suppression order. However, the fact is that I have given Senator Chaney an undertaking that I will find out what I can about the possibility of the NCSC being made aware of the contents of the proceedings in so far as they are relevant to its responsibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: The point raised by Senator Knowles is an important one-namely, that it is important that the proceedings and trials in courts not be prejudiced by publicity which may poison the minds of those who have to assess the guilt or innocence of those who are brought to trial. I am sure that that would be a factor weighing in the mind of the magistrate. Whether it is a sufficient factor to counterbalance the interest of a national organisation such as the National Companies and Securities Commission is something that I am prepared to try to find an answer to.

I do not believe that the Attorney-General has any immediate role open to him. Once again, I can undertake to discover what I can. If, by the end of the proceedings here this afternoon, I have not received sufficient information or a full answer, I undertake to provide it to the honourable senator when it becomes available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice whether he has seen a report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald on the arrest and possible extradition of Sergio Buschmann in the United States, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Australian police had notified Interpol in Washington of the flight's US touchdown.
Is this report correct? How could this happen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have before me a copy of the article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. The report is not accurate. However, it is important to outline a sequence of events involving the Australian Bureau of Interpol, which is headquartered at the Australian Federal Police headquarters here in Canberra. I am advised as follows. Mr Buschmann departed Australia on a Japan Airlines flight at 8.40 p.m. on Sunday, 11 June. At 9.58 a.m. on Monday, 12 June, Interpol Australia, in accordance with its usual process of notifying transit of requesting countries, provided to Interpol Tokyo and Interpol Santiago advice of Mr Buschmann's departure details from Australia. That was the extent of the information relayed from the Australian Bureau of Interpol to the transit and requesting country.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that at 11.40 p.m. on 12 June Interpol Tokyo apparently informed Interpol Santiago, Interpol Washington, Interpol Amsterdam and Interpol Headquarters that Mr Buschmann had departed Japan at 9.40 p.m. that day by Japan Airlines for Amsterdam through Anchorage, Alaska. The extent of the disclosure of Mr Buschmann's departure by the Australian Bureau of Interpol was confined to the advice to Interpol Tokyo and Interpol Santiago. The advice reaching Washington was that passed to it by the Tokyo Bureau.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that Qantas Airways Ltd has recruited a number of Japanese speaking cabin attendants for the Australia-Japan route, including 22 from overseas in the last 12 months? Is it true that restrictive practices by the union have denied Qantas the basic employer's right of using these Japanese speaking cabin attendants to maximum effect for the Japan flights for which they were recruited?

—There are two questions. First, is Qantas recruiting Japanese speaking flight attendants overseas? I do not have an answer to that from Qantas, but I have seen the press reports. I assume it is true, but I will have it checked out. Secondly, I do not know whether union restrictions have prevented the optimum use of those who have been recruited. I will check that out with Mr Willis and see what can be done about it, if it is indeed true.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EDTA: USE IN TREATMENT OF HEART DISEASE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of reports widely circulated in the media in Western Australia criticising his recent statement concerning use of the drug known as EDTA in the treatment of heart disease? Do these reports quote Senator Knowles as alleging that Australia is the only country in the world which does not authorise the use of EDTA for this purpose? Can the Minister inform honourable senators whether this allegation is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of those press reports and I am aware of their being sourced to Senator Knowles. As I said last Friday, one has to be careful in dealing with matters of this nature. For laypersons to make allegations about the properties of drugs is a risky thing. What worries me about the allegations that are being persisted with is that it would seem that claims about outcomes for certain forms of drug treatment are coming from people not qualified to draw those conclusions. They fly in the face of findings by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council and by the National Heart Foundation. Senator Giles asked me whether it was true that Senator Knowles has said that Australia is the only country in the world which bans the use of EDTA for a form of treatment. I have before me the Senate Hansard of 9 June in which Senator Knowles is reported as saying by way of interjection:

ANSWER.PARA: Why is Australia the only place in the world which does not allow it?

She was referring to the use of the drug. Australia is not the only place in the world whose drug evaluation authorities have made this decision. The United States Food and Drug Administration has a similar view to that of the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council. It does not permit the use of this drug for the form of treatment referred to by Senator Knowles.

This is a sensitive matter. People suffering from heart disease obviously want to use whatever means are possible for treatment. It is for the professionally qualified advisory bodies of the Government to assess forms of medical treatment. Unless there is evidence from professionally qualified bodies-and if that evidence exists it should be presented to the proper people to make the evaluation-that there ought to be further re-examination, then proselytising in the community that a wonder drug exists when the drug has been evaluated and has not been approved for that treatment is the worst form of `comfort' that can be given because it raises an expectation that may not be real.

I am not qualified to say whether this drug should or should not be used. What I am qualified to say is that it is the properly qualified body that should make the assessment. If there is any evidence that the previous assessment of the qualified body is wrong, the matter should be resubmitted to that body. To carry on a public campaign like this is the worst sort of thing that can be done to people who suffer from heart complaints and who have a real anxiety about their futures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware that, despite the fact that the exposure draft of the recently passed telecommunications Bill was released on 22 May and that the absolute deadline for comment was 3 April, the responsible Norfolk Island Minister did not receive a copy until 11 April-more than one week after the deadline? In view of the fact that the Cabinet and legislation handbook clearly requires full and adequate consultation with the Norfolk Island administration and that the Norfolk Island Government remains very concerned about a number of important technical and policy issues, will the Government address the serious concern of the Norfolk Island Government in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that the Minister received a copy of the draft on 11 April. If he did, that is obviously a bit rough. I will have to see what I can do about it. I will advise Senator Boswell as soon as I can as to how we propose to correct what is obviously an anomaly and a difficult situation.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of a heavy duplication of departure times by the two domestic airlines on routes around Australia? What can be done about this harmful practice, which severely limits the choice of departure times for travel to and from the less populous States of Australia? Does the Government expect that deregulation of the domestic airline industry next year will reduce parallel scheduling, a practice which would not be tolerated in any other developed country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australians, I suspect, were in the past more conscious of the inconvenience of parallel scheduling than anybody else. There used to be fewer flights. When I first entered Parliament, for example, one had the choice of coming to the east at midday or midnight. There has been a significant improvement in the last 15 years. A survey last year by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics showed that about 45 per cent of all flights in 1987-88 were parallel scheduled. However, it also found that the practice was more common on the high density routes-Sydney-Melbourne in particular, I suppose-where the disbenefits of parallel scheduling are less pronounced because the frequency of flights is much greater anyway. So the situation may not be quite as bad as the 45 per cent figure suggests.

ANSWER.PARA: The amount of parallel scheduling has been blamed-probably justifiably-on the two-airline policy. The Government has already decided to deregulate the domestic airlines. It is expected that that will lead to a greater range of service, particularly if, as some people expect, one of the new entrants is based in Brisbane and will, therefore, have a different home port from both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines, which are both based in Melbourne. That is therefore likely to generate a different pattern of services, at least, I suspect, on the east coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. Are you aware that at the moment three parliamentary staff are entering the bathrooms in each senator's office suite apparently to count the number of lavatories? Is it not a fact that each senator's office has one lavatory? Would it not be possible to calculate the total number of lavatories by reference to the plans of Parliament House and thereby avoid this enormous waste of manpower?

—In reply to Senator Chapman: I was about to make a comment about the types of questions I receive, but I do not think I ought to. I am unaware of what Senator Chapman has described. I will take the question on notice and get him an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It was announced yesterday that Sarich Technologies had signed a licensing agreement with General Motors to manufacture, use and sell Sarich engine technology worldwide. Has the Government been involved in any discussions with Sarich Technologies to ensure that the maximum manufacturing and production of Sarich Technologies' products can be achieved in Australia and hence improve Australia's terms of trade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the press reports of the announcement made by Sarich Technologies. One of the difficulties about interpreting the press reports is that the nature of the agreement, its size and such things are described as being commercially in confidence and are not included in the newspaper reports. I can say, however, that for a long time the Government has had discussions with Mr Sarich. At an earlier stage the Automotive Industry Authority indicated that it was prepared to support further development of the Sarich engine in Australia by a grant under the Automotive Industry Authority Act. But a condition of such a grant, of course, which was made clear to Mr Sarich, was that manufacturing should follow the further development of the engine in Australia. In fact, that is a condition in the Automotive Industry Authority legislation. It is fair to say, on that basis, that the offer was not acceptable to Mr Sarich. While further development work will take place in Australia supported by some of the international companies, I think it is fair to say that it is unlikely that the lead manufacturing plant will be in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Both the Federal and State governments have sought to secure manufacture of the engine in Australia. I believe that Mr Sarich has sought to do that himself, but I am not sure that that is, by any stretch of the imagination, a possibility at this stage. Work commissioned on behalf of the Government in conjunction with Sarich Technologies into the feasibility of a manufacturing plant in Australia showed that the engine could be manufactured profitably in Australia but that it would be manufactured more profitably in, perhaps, the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Minister for Justice, is about the arrest of Mr Buschmann. I note that United States immigration authorities were acting on a warrant from Interpol in arresting Mr Buschmann. Did Interpol request Australian authorities to arrest Mr Buschmann? If so, why was such action not taken instead of deporting him?

—I believe that Interpol sent an alert to the Australian Bureau of Interpol indicating that there was a concern and an interest on the part of the Chilean Government in relation to Mr Buschmann. I am not sure that any warrant was out which was asked to be implemented by the Interpol Bureau here in Australia. I do not believe that the proceedings which might have been formally authorised under extradition arrangements had been instigated in a way which required the Australian Government to give a formal response. Because Mr Buschmann had committed breaches of Australia's immigration laws, I understand that it was thought appropriate to deal with him under that particular regime. Indeed, that is what was done.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I got the impression from the Minister's answer that he was not sure whether there was a warrant out for his arrest. He indicated that there was an alert. I ask the Minister whether he could get that information before the Senate gets up today and let us know.
—I undertake to do that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. During last week's discussions between departmental personnel and Mr Sergio Buschmann in Perth, is it a fact that only one route was nominated for Mr Buschmann's travel to Sweden, or was a variety of route options offered to Mr Buschmann, as stated by Senator McKiernan yesterday? In view of the answer given by Senator Tate, would the Minister outline the measures taken by the Department to guarantee the secrecy of the route by which Mr Buschmann and his companion, Mr Rojas, left the country? Was Mr Buschmann made cognisant of the details of the final proposed route to Sweden, of the airports at which landings were to be made and of the different carriers which would be operating the relevant aircraft flights? Did Mr Buschmann's correct name appear on any transit papers and passenger lists, or was information about his itinerary made specifically available to any airline personnel? Bearing in mind Senator Tate's answer, was the alert from Interpol passed on to Mr Buschmann so that he knew about that? Finally, what measures are now being pursued by the Government to bring about the release of Mr Buschmann and Mr Rojas from their detention in the United States and to provide them with safe passage to their destinations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of Senator Jenkins's question about the route taken and whether Mr Buschmann was given any options is that, he was offered a choice of several possible travel routes. He chose the route that was taken. The second part of the question was whether, in view of what Senator Tate has said in Question Time today, I would outline the measures taken by the Department to guarantee the secrecy of the route. The departmental brief that I have here says that the Department discussed Mr Buschmann's route only with him and Dr Ian Alexander, in whose custody he had been placed. It would seem from Senator Tate's answer that the Department also discussed the route with some other government agencies. I shall have to inquire as to what discussions took place and the nature of those discussions. The third part of the question was whether Mr Buschmann was made cognisant of the details of the final proposed route. He was advised of the flight plan provided by the airline, which included the various carriers.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked about Mr Buschmann's name appearing on the passenger list. The Department of Immigration does not control the details which appear on passenger lists. But I am advised that his name did appear on the passenger list. His itinerary was supplied at the time of the booking of the airline ticket, as was the fact that he was a deportee. After what Senator Tate has had to say, all I can say is that the Immigration Department has no knowledge of discussions between any Australian Government agency and anyone in Interpol or the United States. I shall have to inquire further to give a proper answer to that question.

The last question concerned measures being pursued by the Government to bring about the release of Mr Buschmann. I indicated in the Senate yesterday that the Government has made representations to the United States concerning both Mr Buschmann and Mr Rojas. I shall report to the Senate as soon as we have received the results of the inquiries that we have made of the United States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I have previously asked Senator Robert Ray to ensure that, when Mr Buschmann left the country, the secrecy of his route be handled in such a way as did not make him vulnerable to any activity against him so that he could have safe passage through to Sweden. The Minister replied:

QUESTION.PARA: We have no intention of placing Mr Buschmann in a situation where his life may be endangered or he cannot travel back to Sweden, where he has refugee status.
Does the Minister consider that those words have been kept to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that Mr Buschmann's safety is in danger at the moment. I do not think he is being held in such a way as to damage his health. But I will have to inquire into that. I am not aware of either the question Senator Jenkins asked Senator Robert Ray or the answer that he gave. I will check both of those and let Senator Jenkins know if I have any further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the proposed Evidence (Closed-Circuit Television) Ordinance, which is to allow evidence on closed-circuit television to be given by child sexual abuse victims. While welcoming that initiative and congratulating the Government on taking it, what arrangements have been made to monitor the success of this initiative and report on it and, if it is successful, to ensure that the benefits are extended to other jurisdictions in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact and would be of interest to Senator McMullan and to Senator Reid primarily as senators for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) that such an innovation which is, as I understand it, an Australian first should occur in this Territory. The scheme involves children giving evidence on video in a separate room. That video will be shown live in court. Apparently, the idea came from the experience of magistrates in Canberra. It is the brain child, particularly, of Ron Cahill, the ACT Chief Magistrate, who indicated:

ANSWER.PARA: In the normal court surroundings in the presence of the person involved we've had instances where it's been so traumatic the child has just completely seized up and been unable to give any intelligible evidence to the prosecutor, let alone be cross-examined.

I believe Mr Cahill is the patron of the National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect and has a very real interest and concern in this field. For that reason, the Government was persuaded at quite considerable expense to install video equipment after 1 August in the court in Childers Street in Canberra. As indicated by Senator McMullan's question, the idea is that this be a type of active law reform rather than simply a matter of recommendations in a report tabled in the Parliament. It is intended that the Law Reform Commission will examine the operation of this video link and report on it so that together the Law Reform Commission and a contracted psychologist will provide a report which will then become the basis of law reform initiatives in other jurisdictions. Indeed, the idea is that the Canberra experiment find favour with other jurisdictions so that children about whose state or fate allegations to do with sexual abuse are made may be able to give their evidence in a way which is not as traumatic and difficult for them as apparently is the case at the moment. I believe that the experiment will have effect as a model for other jurisdictions, not only in relation to child abuse cases; it could also have far reaching implications for the Family Court of Australia as a means of obtaining evidence. The experiment, under the aegis of Chief Magistrate Ron Cahill, is to be welcomed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, to the Minister for Finance, relates to the entitlements to lump sum superannuation payments of retiring Commonwealth public servants. Is the Minister aware of payment practices of the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office (AGRBO) which have resulted in delays in payment authorisation, causing financial loss to entitled retirees? Does the Minister endorse the position taken by both AGRBO and the Department of Finance that the Commonwealth is not bound by commercial practices in meeting legal obligations to retirees who have elected to receive a lump sum payment? Will the Minister investigate the practice and use his discretionary power to see that justice is done to any retirees who have been financially disadvantaged by the delays in processing payment claims by AGRBO?

—There is an accepted normal period for processing which, I think, is in the vicinity of six weeks, but I am not sure of that. Certainly there have been complaints that it has taken more than six weeks. Sometimes that is the fault of the contributor for not supplying information in time or not supplying complete information, but I cannot remember the details of that. However, in at least one case the delay was clearly excessive and I made an act of grace payment to the person concerned, but I would check that as well. —My question about taxation reform in Australia is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to recent calls in some quarters for incentive in Australian taxes to be restored. Is the Hawke Government united in its polices on the taxation of unearned capital gains?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is unequivocally yes. The Government is entirely united about the need to have taxes on unearned capital gains. Indeed, the Government regards it as an essential component of its taxation system. It is essential because it is necessary to have a capital gains tax as a net under the income tax system. The basis of most tax avoidance schemes was the conversion of what otherwise would have been taxable income into tax free capital gains. That, of course, refers to the bad old days of the Fraser Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition has an official policy of watering down the capital gains tax so that it would not apply after a time lag of five years. Some particular members of the Liberal Party, principally Mr Elliott and Mr McLachlan, want to get rid of capital gains taxation altogether. That is because of their strong self-interest in the matter. If there were no capital gains tax, after Mr Elliott and Mr McLachlan had diddled the rest of Elders IXL Ltd shareholders by issuing themselves 1c paid shares which carry the same rights for bonus issue as fully paid shares and after they had diddled all the other shareholders by watering down the company's capital, they could then sell their bonus shares and pick up an enormous capital gain which they would now have to pay tax on. They want to get rid of the capital gains tax so that they can diddle not only the other shareholders of Elders but also other taxpayers. That is their position. On the other hand, there are some more responsible people in the Liberal Party like Senator Hill, for example. In his maiden speech on 9 September 1981, in criticism of the then taxation system, Senator Hill said:
It taxes income to the extent that it increases wealth but not capital gains or windfall gains . . .
Later, he said:
We cannot forever remain the only highly developed nation without some form of capital or equivalent taxation at the Federal level.

At the time I commended Senator Hill for having the courage to say that in the Liberal Party. I commend his speech-an excellent speech in other respects, apart from that-to all other members of the Liberal Party.

Finally, Mr President, I wish to table a schedule of protests that have been lodged by the Government, as requested by Senator Chaney a few days ago, to various Chinese authorities. There are about four pages altogether. Although some of the individuals concerned are being held in custody--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—The abuse of human rights goes back to 1981 or 1982; we have not covered the protests to the end of that time.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you are completely out of order and I will allow another question.

—Mr President, I draw your attention to an editorial in the Canberra Times on Wednesday which commends a decision by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Stewart West, to appoint a six-member committee to report on `any proposed works (either external or internal) which could have a significant impact on the building or its function'. What discussions did the Minister have with the Parliament through its Presiding Officers before taking this apparently unilateral decision? As the Minister stated in his press release on this matter of 9 July that the Parliament now holds the design of the new Parliament House in trust for the people of Australia, do you and Madam Speaker accept the Minister's dictate that responsibility for the building in its function as a Parliament belongs not only with the Parliament, but also with the Government? When did the Parliament forfeit to the Executive Government its right to control the parliamentary functions of Parliament House? Why is the right to appoint all six members of the proposed Committee limited to the Executive Government with the Parliament having no say whatsoever? What role, if any, will the Parliament's own New Parliament House Committee have in this matter? What action do you and Madam Speaker intend to take to ensure that Parliament retains control of its own home?

—Senator Michael Baume has raised a matter which is of great conce rn to the Speaker and me and one which I think should be of concern to all honourable senators. The Minister for Administrative Services had no consultation whatsoever with the Speaker or me. I recently received a letter from the Minister detailing the proposal that Senator Michael Baume mentioned. Madam Speaker and I have serious reservations about the matter. As recently as yesterday we wrote to the Minister advising him of our concerns and requesting that the proposal be withdrawn forthwith. I am sure that this is the course of action that all of you would have wished me to take. So that honourable senators are fully informed on the matter, I now table Minister West's letter to me advising of the proposal. I will keep the Senate fully informed on this important matter. If I have missed any part of Senator Michael Baume's question, I will give further advice to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have that document incorporated in Hansard. It would be of great interest.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator the Hon. K. W. Sibraa
President of the Senate
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2601
Dear Mr President

I am writing to convey to you a decision which the Government has recently made about the protection of the design of the Parliament House, a national asset in which both the Parliament and the Government have an interest.

In April this year at the ceremony to mark the transfer of the formal gardens to the Parliament, I foreshadowed the fact that the Government was giving consideration to this issue. I believe that the arrangements which are set out in this letter complement the Presiding Officers' responsibilities in relation to the building on behalf of Parliament and recognise the importance of providing an opportunity to protect the building which is held in trust on behalf of the people of Australia. In view of the importance of this decision, I am arranging for a media release to be issued shortly after you receive this letter.
In essence, the Government has decided to set in train arrangements which will:

return to both Houses of Parliament the powers to decide on changes to the design of the Parliament House which might have a potentially significant impact on the internal design or function of the building, in the same way that the Parliament deals with building or other works in the external parts of the building and precincts;

establish a six member advisory panel of experts to assess all proposed capital or other works intended to be carried out within the precincts of the Parliament and to report to the Parliament on any capital or other works which it considers might have a potentially significant impact on the design or function of Parliament House;

as its first task, make the panel responsible for advising on regulations which would provide a detailed definition of those categories of works which are to be regarded as having a potentially significant impact.
I have set out at ATTACHMENT A to this letter the details of the Government's decision. The background to the decision and further details about the issues involved are at ATTACHMENT B.
There are some aspects of the decision on which I would particularly wish to comment.

In agreeing to these arrangements, the Government has been concerned to avoid circumstances arising where unregulated alterations to the building's design would occur, comparable in quality to the kind of alterations made to the Provisional Parliament House. A lessening of the Parliament building's value as a national asset would inevitably occur. I am sure you would join me in wishing to avoid the possibility of any resulting criticism of the Government's and the Parliament's failure to act to protect the nation's billion dollar investment.

I should make it clear that the arrangements are to be applied to the entire building, including the Ministerial Wing. The Presiding Officers, the Minister responsible for the Ministerial Wing and the Parliament itself will all have access to professional expert advice on proposed works which may affect the integrity of the building's design.

The arrangements involved are to be given effect through amendments to the Parliament Act 1974. The Government intends introducing the amendments as soon as possible, with a view to securing their passage in the 1989 Budget Sittings.

The decision provides that the appointment of three members of the panel should be a matter for agreement between the Presiding Officers and the Minister responsible for the Ministerial Wing. I believe it would be helpful, as a preliminary step, for us to confer on the process of selecting these members as soon as possible, in the knowledge, of course, that the formation of the panel is subject to the legislation to be put before the Parliament. For my part, I am arranging to approach both the Institutes of Architects and Engineers seeking their cooperation in providing a list of suitable nominees from whom we can make a selection. I would also expect that we could agree on the selection of one of the three professional experts for appointment as the panel's chairperson.

Once the advisory panel is formed, the Government feels that the provision of the necessary secretariat support for its operation should properly reside with the Parliament. Whether this should be through the Joint House Department or some other suitable arrangement is a matter for your judgment. The Government has agreed to funding of $100,000 a year for the panel's operation. This is based on an assessment that the panel would probably need to meet three times a year to consider proposed works.
I am writing in similar terms to Madam Speaker.
Yours sincerely
STEWART WEST
ATTACHMENT A
PROTECTION OF THE DESIGN OF PARLIAMENT HOUSE-SUMMARY OF THE GOVERNMENT'S DECISION
1. The Government has decided that amendments to the Parliament Act 1974 are to be proposed to provide for the following:
(a) the establishment of a six member advisory panel

(i) having the functions of considering and assessing all proposed capital or other works intended to be carried out within the precincts of the Parliament (as defined by the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988;
(ii) reporting to the Parliament on any capital or other works considered by the panel to have a potentially significant impact on the design or function of Parliament House (see paragraph 2 below);

(iii) comprising the Chairpersons of the Australian Heritage Commission and the National Capital Planning Authority, both on an ex officio basis, a representative of the Department of Administrative Services, and three other members recognised as being among the most experienced and respected in Australia in the professions of architecture and engineering, and with legislative provision to enable the group to co-opt other professionals whose expertise is not already represented on the group; and

(iv) whose members are to be appointed for three year, renewable terms, with membership to be agreed between the Presiding Officers and the Minister responsible for the Ministerial Wing of Parliament House (currently the Minister for Administrative Services).

(b) for any proposed capital or other works within the precincts (as defined by the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988) which are the subject of reports made in accordance with sub-paragraph 1 (a) (ii) above

(i) reports from the Presiding Officers or the Minister responsible for the Ministerial Wing, are to be laid before each House of Parliament at the same time as the reports in sub-paragraph 1 (a) (ii) above; and
(ii) each House, by positive resolution, is to approve of a proposal for capital or other works before proceeding with the works.
2. The Government has also agreed that:
(a) the detailed definition of those categories of works with potentially significant impact (see sub-paragraph 1 (a) (ii) above) should be considered by the panel at its first meeting;
(b) regulations defining the relevant categories of works should be prepared after advice from the panel, and be considered by Government before being made; and
(c) costs for remuneration, travel and expenses for advisory panel members should be set at $100,000 per annum.
ATTACHMENT B
PROTECTION OF THE DESIGN OF PARLIAMENT HOUSE
Background to the Government's Decision

1. During the design and construction of the Parliament building, both Houses of Parliament were empowered by the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979 to approve the design of the building and its surrounds. The ultimate decision on the building's design lay with Parliament itself which had access to professional expert advice from the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) about design and construction issues.

2. The situation now is that some aspects affecting design require Parliament's approval; some involve the Presiding Officers only; responsibility for others is unclear. No provision exists for expert assessments of any proposed capital or other works in the building or its precincts.

3. The provisions of the PHCA Act empowering both Houses to approve internal design charges were superseded by proclamation of the Parliamentary Precincts Act in August 1988. Responsibility for decisions on changes within the building thereby passed from the Houses of Parliament to the Presiding Officers.

4. Power to change the design of the outside of the building and external precincts still lies with the Houses of Parliament through the Parliament Act 1974 which provides for positive resolutions of both Houses before carrying out building or other work. Whether internal courtyards are covered by the Parliament Act is not immediately apparent.
Issues Considered
Where should responsibility lie for approval of capital or other works with the potential to alter significantly the building's interior or exterior design or precincts

5. During design and construction, PHCA balanced two objectives: producing an efficient, functional national Parliament; and producing an asset forming a premier part of Australia's national estate and heritage.

6. Responsibility for maintenance of the first objective has passed from PHCA to Joint House Department (JHD). Continuing responsibility for the second has not passed to any organisation. Five parliamentary departments and the Executive can decide to alter the building or its precincts and in doing so perhaps compromise its value as a national heritage asset. None of these organisations is responsible for retaining or protecting the design of the building as approved by Parliament, or for maintaining a balance between the two objectives.

7. Protection of national heritage assets is well recognised through both practical and legislative means but such assets are often not given adequate protection until they have acquired historic significance by which time they may have been irrevocably altered. Effective protection arrangements need to be instituted for Parliament House before any significant alterations are made.

8. The Government believes that the Parliament is the most appropriate body to be responsible for future decisions which might have a significant impact on the building and its surrounds. It has therefore decided to revert to the arrangements applying before August 1988, when positive resolutions of both Houses were required to approve actions that could result in significant changes to the design of the building. The Parliament Act 1974 provides for such resolutions with regard to buildings or other work in the external parts of the building and precincts; it is logical therefore to extend its scope to cover the interior of Parliament House.

9. Only those few proposals judged as likely to have a significant impact on the building's design should come before parliament itself. The situation would be comparable to the ten year design and construction period during which Parliament considered the design and its development on no more than 4 or 5 occasions.
Whether it is possible to retain the building's and precinct's design integrity as completed, by ensuring professional expertise is used to design and assess proposed changes

10. While changes to the building will be required over time, works carried out through JHD are not assessed qualitatively or against the existing design. Advice similar in range and expertise to that available to PHCA during the design/construction phases is not available for JHD to use in assessing proposals. The Government is aware of an arrangement between JHD and Mitchell/Giurgola & Thorp Architects whereby their advice is sought on how best to implement changes. This does not appear, however, to extend to assessments of the impact of changes on the existing design. Nor is there a regulatory requirement for the advice from the Architect to be sought, acknowledged, heeded or reported to Parliament. In any event, the arrangement is only part of a much larger structure needed to encompass properly all changes to the building.

11. Just as it was essential for PHCA to have access to and use a range of architectural and engineering expertise to develop the design and construct the Parliament, the Government considers the same should hold for any future capital or other works. That is, Parliament will need access to a similar or expanded range or expertise and it will need to be required to take that advice into account if the integrity of the building design is to be maintained effectively.

12. The Government has determined to establish by legislation an advisory panel of experts to report to the Presiding Officers and to the Minister for Administrative Services (in his capacity as Minister responsible for the Ministerial Wing) on all proposed capital or other works in the precincts, inside or outside the building. The advisory group is to comprise three professional experts drawn from the spheres of architecture and engineering and the Chairpersons of both the Australian Heritage Commission and the National Capital Planning Authority on an ex officio basis, as well as a representative from the Department of Administrative Services. The panel will have power to co-opt other experts where this proves essential to its function.
13. The Government has decided that the panel's membership is to be agreed between the Presiding Officers and the Minister responsible for the Ministerial Wing.

14. The legislation will make it mandatory for the panel to report to Parliament whenever it considered proposed capital or other works might significantly affect the master plan of the building's design as embodied in the developed design report on new Parliament House approved by parliament in November 1986, and as embodied in the building formally handed over to Parliament during 1988. Mandatory, tabled panel reports, together with reports from the Presiding Officers seeking positive resolutions of both Houses of parliament to undertake such significant capital or other works anywhere within the precincts would thereby enable Parliament to take informed decisions on proposals with potentially significant design impacts.

15. By requiring panel scrutiny of all proposed capital or other works (regardless of their purported significance) all parties with powers to propose works would be obliged to use appropriate expertise either to prepare or advise on proposals before they are subjected to the mandatory panel scrutiny. To neglect such steps would run the risk of the panel declaring the proposal's impact significant due to poor or amateur design and results in reports to Parliament. Obliging the use of appropriate expertise should promote the avoidance of ill-considered, and often unsightly alterations that were the result of 60 years of unregulated modification of the Provisional Parliament House.
The guidance which could be given on alterations which might have a potentially significant effect on the building's design

16. Many elements make up the integrity of the building's design. Affecting any of them potentially affects the whole. Rather than attempting to define `potentially significant effects' immediately, the Government considered that a more practical alternative would be for the panel to start with the approved design as constructed and fitted out and to assess detailed definition of categories of works to be covered, having in mind the following specific aspects:
(a) quality of design and the finishes of the building and precincts which comprise the national asset;

(b) ceremonial or public areas or those seen by official parliamentary or government guests-broadly, the areas within the curved walls and along the east-west axis across the House and Senate entries;

(d) displays and display areas.
17. Once the Government has considered the panel's assessment regulations will need to be made defining the categories of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time I was asked a question by Senator Newman concerning the Defence Housing Authority. It is correct that a spouse representative has had full observer status on the Defence Housing Authority since the beginning of 1988. It is also correct that the Defence Housing Authority Act was amended in November 1988 to formalise this representation. Pending the appointment of a formal spouse representative, the nominated spouse observer, Mrs Lorraine Sanderson, has continued to attend meetings of the Authority. Mrs Sanderson has participated fully in the deliberations of the Authority. Much of the Authority's discussions are largely informal, with decisions being reached by consensus. Thus, the lack of voting rights has not impeded Mrs Sanderson's very considerable contribution to the Authority on behalf of Service spouses.

ANSWER.PARA: The amendment to the Defence Housing Authority Act allowed for the appointment of two additional members to the Authority. The delay in the formal appointment of the spouse representative has been due to difficulties in settling on the second additional member and a perceived need to go forward to the Executive Council with proposals for both appointments at the same time. Mrs Sanderson now has indicated that, for personal reasons, she will be unable to continue on the Authority. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has been in consultation with the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses with a view to identifying a suitable replacement. That selection and formal appointment process will be finalised as soon as possible.

With regard to the last part of Senator Newman's question, the spouse representative will be provided with funds to enable travel to meet with spouses' groups and to examine defence housing issues. Mrs Sanderson's travel costs throughout her time with the Authority have been met. She has travelled at government expense, both with the Authority and separately, to represent spouses' interests on defence housing issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Bills. They represent five major areas of reform. The first and most significant relates to share buy backs. The Bill is long-awaited and has been strongly supported by the business community. The Opposition has, been calling for it for two years. Nevertheless, we are pleased that it has finally reached this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The second major part of the package relates to a flexible accelerated security transfer system. The Bill provides for the pilot testing of the Australian Stock Exchange's proposed scheme for a flexible accelerated security transfer system in an effort to ensure that backlogs do not develop and delays are kept to a minimum in the transfer and registration of securities.

The third area relates to the licensing of participants in the securities and futures industries. These provisions prevent the enforcement of a contract by a person acting as adviser or dealer without a licence. Securities dealers, futures brokers and advisers will still require licences but their representatives will not. Brokers and advisers will be made more fully liable for the conduct of their representatives. While supporting this deregulation, we will be watching to ensure that investors are adequately protected under the reform.

Fourthly, the legislation will facilitate computerisation of corporate affairs commissions (CACs). Original documents will not always be made available for inspection. If the CAC can provide a computer print-out or visual display, access to the original will not be necessary.

The fifth area relates to a user-pays system for the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) and amends the fees Acts to companies, companies' acquisition of shares, the futures industry and the securities industry code. A new Companies (Fees: Taxation Component) Bill accompanies each amendment to the fees Act to ensure that there is no power to impose fees that might contain an element of taxation. There is provision for the NCSC, among other things, to charge a fee when computer related documents are issued; increase the limit on the size of the fee; and charge a deposit where the fee cannot be ascertained straightaway. Fees, in monetary terms, may not exceed $5,000-an increase from $1,000-but they may be described in percentage terms. The Opposition supports that proposal. As I indicated, the Opposition supports the package of Bills and wishes it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the Opposition welcomes the Bills, even though, of course, Senator Hill mentioned that it had been waiting for them for a few years. Having said that, I also wish them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four significant changes are encompassed within the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. The first concerns computer crime and implements recommendations of the Gibbs committee. We support this reform which creates offences in relation to access to and damaging of data. The second significant change relates to penalties. The Bill provides for imposition of pecuniary penalties and imprisonment and increases fines substantially. We support that part of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The third area of significant change relates to spent convictions. This has been an area which has caused the Opposition concern and about which two amendments of substance were moved in the other place. It seems to us that some of the obvious exclusions-that is, convictions which should not be capable of being spent under such schemes-are set out in the Bill but others are not. There is a catch-all provision that says that other cases may be dealt with by regulation. Therefore, we proposed an amendment that the Bill not come into operation until the full range of exceptions has been set out. We also proposed an amendment to new section 85zw which provides for a person whose conviction is spent to make a positive assertion that he has not been charged with or convicted of an offence. I will come back to the matter of spent convictions which is our principal concern in the Bill.

The fourth area of significant change relates to the powers of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). The Bill gives the DPP power to grant wider forms of indemnity to witnesses than he has presently and we support that change. The Bill also gives the DPP an unlimited power to issue ex officio indictments. We concluded that that was justifiable, except in the case of war crimes, and we moved an amendment in the other place which the Government agreed to. We are pleased that by that process war crimes became an exception. I think that it is unnecessary at this time to go through the reasons; I just make the comment that there was a long and difficult debate in this chamber and the Government seemed to take a different position from what it finally concluded. Nevertheless, we are pleased that it accepted our position in that regard.

That brings me back to the question of spent convictions and our amendments which we regard as of importance. We recognise, however, that a number of the amendments, particularly to part 8, as I understand it, of the National Crimes Authority Act, are to commence on 1 July 1989. We are anxious that we do not in any way delay the implementation of these provisions and the others that I have indicated we support.

We had negotiations with the Government as to whether the Bill might be proceeded with on the basis that the spent convictions part was removed. That was not our suggestion because we support it in principle. We just had the reservations that I have outlined. However, for a while there was a suggestion by the Government that it would remove the whole of that package. That day has now passed and it decided not to do that. It was put to us that the Government would withdraw the whole of the Bill rather than have it dealt with without the spent convictions provision. We were unhappy that that would occur and, therefore, decided to facilitate passage of the total Bill today.

In doing so, we stress that we stand by the amendments that we moved in the other place and the merit of those amendments. We still put them to the Government for its consideration in the future and indicate to the Senate that, upon coming to government, we will also reconsider the provisions in relation to spent convictions and at that time consider whether the law should be further amended to encompass the areas of concern that we put down in a much more comprehensive form in the other place.
