SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is commencing its debate on the Patents Amendment Bill 1989 but I understand that we will deal only with the second reading stage because there are some amendments to be moved at the committee stages. Currently, Australian patents are granted for a term of 16 years. Applications may be made to the courts on two separate grounds for extensions of up to an additional 10 years. The Bill will change all of that procedure. The Bill was first introduced into the House of Representatives on 3 June 1988 and, more than 12 months later, it has come back with a number of Government amendments which make it a much better Bill: the Government's amendments improve it. The Bill arises from a report prepared in August 1984 by the Industrial Property Advisory Committee which recommended that all extension of term provisions for patents be abolished.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill abolishes existing provisions for extensions for all inventions but introduces a new scheme to enable extension of patent term for pharmaceutical products. The Government decided on special treatment for pharmaceutical patents as part of a plan to develop the pharmaceutical industry in Australia. However, I note that that plan appears to be faltering. I observed in an article in the Australian of 13 June this year that Dr John Stocker, the Managing Director of AMRAD, one of a tiny group of Australian companies successfully developing new pharmaceuticals, recently addressed a science and industry forum in Melbourne and accused the Federal Government of sabotaging its own pharmaceutical industry development plan through conflicting aims, too much regulation and tax disincentives.

It is very interesting that he chose those three points about which to criticise the Government in relation to its pharmaceutical industry development plan when just this week we have had tabled a draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission which makes similar criticism of the Government for not looking to the proper development of industry because of conflicting aims, too much regulation and tax disincentives. It appears that that pharmaceutical plan is faltering and Dr Stocker has said that unless urgent measures are taken to encourage investment in the industry and remove hindrances, the plan might actually falter.

There were serious defects in the original Bill. For example, it provided for extensions of patent for imported pharmaceutical substances, but not for those from within Australia. So overseas interests were looked after but Australian patentees were not. Many important bodies complained about the serious defects of the Bill. The extension of term provisions in the Bill were fundamentally flawed and required substantial amendment to correct the problems. The Government was clearly in trouble. It took the Bill away for nearly 12 months and now it has brought it back in an amended form. Those amendments address many of the concerns raised by industry but not all the defects.

The coalition parties will move two amendments in the committee stage-one to change the effective commencement date of the Bill with regard to applications for extensions of patent terms by non-pharmaceutical patentees, and a second to reduce the opportunity for a kind of blackmail in the circumstance arising in section 12. I will explain these further in the committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly to the Patents Amendment Bill 1989. It gives effect to the intention announced some time ago by the Government to change the arrangements for patents on pharmaceutical substances, which currently have a life of 16 years. Patentees have been able to apply to the court for an extension of up to 10 years. It has been up to the court to decide whether an extension will be granted. That arrangement is being replaced with what is essentially a guaranteed four-year extension.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for this change relates to the very long period during which a number of pharmaceutical products are exposed to a testing program and an assessment of the results of that testing program. It has been pointed out by a number of pharmaceutical manufacturers and marketers that as soon as a company has a product which it thinks has potential, in order to avoid the possibility that another company may get aboard the bandwagon or lodge a patent before the first company can do so, at that stage, the company should patent the substance. There would be a lot of in-house testing to find out whether the substance was effective for the purposes for which the drug was being developed, and also some preliminary work on safety. It may take some considerable time before the company is sure that it has a product that it wants to go ahead with developing. Following that, of course, there is a much more extensive period during which a whole battery of acute, chronic and delayed toxicity tests are carried out.

Of course, by their very nature, the delayed toxicity tests involve carcinogenicity tests which, in the standard protocol, involve tests on a large number of animals being followed for two years. Normally two species of animals-rats and mice-are watched for at least two years. Autopsies are then conducted and every tissue from every animal is submitted to pathological examination to see whether there are any tumors; the tumors are counted and statistical work is carried out. So the tests, by their very nature, take at least three years. When one adds the other tests, one is often looking at six or eight years before a product which has been patented reaches the point where the company is prepared and able to submit that substance for registration and regulation as a pharmaceutical agent in the market.

Once that substance is submitted, it goes through the assessment procedures by a particular body in each country. In Australia there are various committees that operate under the National Health and Medical Research Council. That process takes quite a long time. It might be eight or even 10 years between the time that a product is patented and the time that it actually appears on the market. For that reason a number of these companies have pointed out that the time frame between that eight or 10 year period and the expiration of the patent after 16 years is perhaps insufficient for them fully to recoup their development costs. In the case of totally new products, that cost is very considerable, for the reasons that I have mentioned. In particular, the carcinogenicity costs run into many hundreds of thousands of dollars just for one battery of tests.

Under the system at the moment, of course, at the end of the 16-year period the company can apply to the courts for an extension of up to 10 years, there being no certainty that that will be granted, there is the possibility that the extension granted may be for less than 10 years. There is also the problem of a lengthy court procedure. This Bill essentially guarantees to the company that it can get a fairly automatic four-year extension. In other words, the patent can be extended up to 20 years.

Given the way in which we operate, the Australian Democrats can see no problem with that procedure. It certainly streamlines the proceedings. I signal that the precedent which this has created is likely to be followed, or attempted to be followed, by the manufacturers of veterinary and agricultural chemicals. Indeed, the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia has already received evidence along those lines, both for and against a similar extension of four years for such products. There are arguments for and against such an extension. I am sure the Government will be put under pressure to extend these provisions to that area. Mention might even have been made of that by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in his second reading speech.

I have some difficulty with the general philosophy of patents. It is implied that the person who develops an idea, in this case a chemical, should have some proprietary rights over that product. These products, by their nature, are products designed to improve the health status of individuals. It concerns me that people in this position are often, of necessity, highly educated people who have been through a public education process. A great deal of their education has been paid for by the community at large. The facilities which they have used during their education have been paid for by the community at large. Even the skills that they bring to bear in pursuing their education are not skills for which they themselves are responsible. Some people have the intellectual equipment to avail themselves of this high level of education and, as a consequence, are able to advance medical knowledge. But to say that that knowledge should be completely privatised, that the person who developed it has the exclusive privilege to exercise a legal proprietary right to exploit that knowledge, is something that needs to be questioned.

I would certainly prefer to see a great deal more public support for research and development. That knowledge, and the products which come from it, should remain in the public domain for the public good, and not be privatised. Although I have some fundamental difficulty with this type of legislation, given the system under which we operate, it seems to me that what the Government is proposing provides at least an administrative improvement on the system as it is at the moment. Therefore, the Democrats have no objection to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate, and particularly for the shortness of their contributions. I note Senator Coulter's general conceptual difficulty with patents. Otherwise, I agree with his comments in relation to the Patents Amendment Bill 1989. Senator Lewis has given notice of two amendments on behalf of the Opposition which the Government will not accept. In respect of one or two comments that he made, he relied on an article in the Australian of Tuesday, which claimed that the so-called pharmaceutical plan was faltering. That article quoted a speech by John Stocker, the Chief Executive of AMRAD, at some conference.

SPEECH.PARA: The pharmaceutical industry in this country is not subject to a plan. Historically, the problem with the pharmaceutical industry has been that it has always been foreign owned and has been tailored, as it were, to provide product for a captive market provided by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It is an industry which has some hangover, as it were, from the previous Government-that period of 30 years during which Opposition senators were in government-industries were encouraged to set up establishments here without any requirements in respect of research and development, exports, or development work to be done in Australia. The Government has looked at the pricing of pharmaceuticals under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Roughly, the prices obtained by drug companies in Australia are about 60 per cent of world market prices. That might be regarded as a success in terms of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme; it is not, of course, a success in terms of manufacturers and people who want to produce and export drugs and other pharmaceutical products from Australia.

We have recently introduced a scheme whereby pharmaceutical companies will be guaranteed higher prices under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in return for commitments relating to research and development and exports from Australia. We are turning what one might describe as branch office companies, and the moribund nature of those institutions, into significant producing companies in Australia which will do research and development here and export goods from here. Four companies have already taken advantage of that scheme and have been awarded higher prices for their products in return for commitments in relation to research and development and exports.

These things will lead to a substantial expansion in the Australian pharmaceutical export capacity and the research and development which is conducted in Australia. Of course, that is what we have to be about in this country. We have to turn pro-active industrial activities into ones which are capable of contributing to the Australian economy in a realistic way. Some of Dr Stocker's remarks may have related to the generic pricing policy which is a different issue and is subject to further discussion by government. I wanted to comment on Senator Lewis's remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not mine, they were Dr Stockman's remarks.
—No, Stocker is his name. I am grateful that Senator Lewis recorded his remarks in Hansard--
—He claimed that the scheme is falling apart.

—It adds a new dimension to the debate in the Senate. We have a new Senator, Senator Stocker, whose remarks are now recorded in Hansard. That is a good thing; his remarks would be infinitely more pertinent than many of the remarks that are made in this chamber by the rest of us. I thank Opposition senators for generally supporting the legislation and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, clause 10, lines 24 to 31, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Continued operation of
Part IX of Principal Act
``10. (1) Part IX of the Principal Act continues to apply to any proceedings that are pending under that Part at the commencement of this section.
``(2) No proceedings are to be commenced under Part IX of the Principal Act after the commencement of this section.''.
(2) Page 9, after subclause 12 (7), add the following new subclause:

``(8) In this section `person interested' means a person who, not later than 3 months after the commencement of this section, lodges, or is given leave by a prescribed court to lodge, a caveat in the proceedings that were pending in relation to a patent under Part IX of the Principal Act.''.

The first amendment does not affect pharmaceutical patentees who have been operating under the assumption that the new four-year extensions regime has been operating since 3 June 1988. What it would do if it is supported by this chamber is that it would give some breathing space to other patentees who might have been commencing proceedings when the Bill was introduced. I believe-I am sure the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) understands-that there would be a number of people who, at the time when this Bill was introduced, with its reference to a cut-off date, would have been in the process of having their patent applications prepared; they would have engaged their patent attorneys and their lawyers; and they really ought to have been given some sort of introductory period. I put it to the chamber that there would not be a flood of applications for extension because of this amendment. Preparing and pursuing an application is expensive. It has been estimated that a maximum of 10 patentees might be affected by this amendment. I put it to the Committee that it would be worth while carrying this amendment for their sake.

The second amendment will ensure that objectors to pharmaceutical patentees transferring to the new four-year extension provisions are bona fide objectors. I point out that clause 12 gives pharmaceutical manufacturers whose patents expired up to two years before introduction of the Bill the opportunity to switch to the new provisions if court proceedings for extension were pending as at 3 June 1988. To preserve the rights of objectors, the clause also gives an interested party the right to object to the switch and, if this objection is not withdrawn within three months, the patentee cannot use the new provisions. Patentees argue that this leaves them open to a form of blackmail because the interested party does not have to give grounds for objecting.

The amendment proposed by the Opposition will give only those parties who have expressed objection to an extension of patents through the courts the right to object to the patentee switching to the new provisions. This preserves the right of bona fide objectors and, indeed, gives objectors a three-month period of grace in which to establish their credentials, while not allowing any interested party to object to the switch for nuisance reasons or simply to gain some advantage in some way or other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated earlier that the Government was not disposed to accept the Opposition amendments. I make one or two general points. The delay in implementing the Government's policy and the possible cost to the Commonwealth of departing from the 3 June 1988 cut-off date for commencing judicial extension proceedings would create difficulty. There are other objections of a general kind, but I will make one observation about the nature of the amendments. On the one hand, the changes that are inherent in Senator Lewis's amendments find favour with the Law Council of Australia. On the other hand, they do not find favour with the clients. The Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which represents the industries which this legislation is designed to help, has expressed the wish that the Bill be passed without amendment as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make a couple of points about amendment No. 1. The opportunity for pharmaceutical manufacturers to commence a judicial extension, which is denied by the Bill from 3 June 1989, is offset by the new provisions enabling an almost automatic extension of four years. That is what they want. The Bill trades a very uncertain possibility, of up to 10 years extension under the old system, involving high legal costs, for an almost certain four years extension with negligible costs. This is about reducing the costs to industries which have very high costs in terms of drug development, for example.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are supporting the Bill.

—Yes, but Senator Lewis's amendment does not, in terms of cost. A strong argument against amendment No. 1 is, of course, the possible cost to the Commonwealth as well. The Department of Community Services and Health wants the 3 June 1988 date because it was stipulated to prevent a rush of protective patent extension applications under the old Act, regardless of the current age of the patent. The costs involved for the Department are very big. The legal costs would be in the order of $150,000 to $200,000. There could also be costs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme wherever patentees were granted an extension of five or 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that determination by the courts of all the outstanding proceedings which could result from the Opposition's amendment could take up to a decade. Senator Lewis is always lecturing me about the pace of change. Every day he tells me that this Government is too slow to do things, yet he has moved an amendment which could involve an industry in that sort of process. It is great for the lawyers! Implementation of the Bill's policy could be delayed for years if Senator Lewis's amendment is carried.

With regard to the second amendment relating to the definition of a person interested, the question is really whether the amendment's additional deterrent effect on vexatious objectors would outweigh the burden on genuine objectors who would be obliged to intervene in the judicial proceedings. We must bear in mind that patentees can already attack an objector's standing as a person interested. In those circumstances there seems to be little merit in the amendment. For those reasons the Government does not accept the proposals put forward by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be understood that the question of whether we can complete the committee stage of this Bill today will depend on whether the Australian Democrats indicate where they stand in regard to these amendments. I say to the Minister, with all due respect, that one of his arguments always is to try to frighten people. He is saying, `I tell you this in terrorem: there has been an estimate that this might extend the period in which these matters can be dealt with by 10 years'. That is absolute bunkum, Minister.
—No, it is not.

—Let me explain to the Minister why it is bunkum. The operating date was 3 June 1988. I think the Minister is saying `A patent application which was lodged on 2 June 1988 may take 10 years to complete, then I accept that a patent application lodged on 3 June-the day after-may take 10 years to complete'. I think that is what the Minister is saying, because these matters frequently take a long time to be completed. But the Government's cut-off date cuts off applications at the knees at that stage. It did not matter how well prepared an application to the Patent Office was at that stage; if it had not been lodged on 3 June, it was cut off. All I am saying is that, clearly, at that stage, there would not have been a large number of patent applications; we understand there might have been 10 patent applications at that stage which were well prepared and could have been lodged almost immediately-within a week. If the original Bill had stated, `Today, 3 June, is when we are introducing it, but we will make the cut-off day, say, 30 June or 10 June, or something of that nature', it would have given those people who had their applications well prepared a chance to lodge them. This amendment would grant that extension. It is as simple as that. The Minister should not try to adopt these arguments which frighten people, because they carry no water with us. Of course, they might carry some with the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not support these amendments. I do not know where that leaves this debate; whether it means that it has become contentious and we cannot complete consideration of it. It seems to me that when one is dealing with a change in the law which involves something like patents-and some of these patents are attached to pharmaceutical agents, which are extremely valuable to the particular companies-necessarily, there will be a requirement to act at a particular time and to act decisively, so that those who attempt to use knowledge about the change to get a pecuniary advantage are unable to do so. It seems to me that what the Opposition is attempting to do is to put the clock back so that some people are allowed to take advantage of something which was not knowledge at the time, but which is knowledge now, and allow them to start a process which could involve the granting of an extension of patent for up to 10 years. However long the legal process took, the patent could be extended for that length of time.

SPEECH.PARA: We certainly accept the Government's position that it is much tidier to introduce this legislation fairly quickly; to make it clear that the uncertain 10-year period is replaced with a reasonably certain four-year period. That is fairer; everybody knows where they stand. My understanding is that there may be as few as two companies that may be involved in the process of actually preparing a case at the relevant time. I think the degree of penalty which is being imposed is quite small.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear from Senator Coulter's remarks that the Australian Democrats will not support our amendments. As the debate is taking place during the luncheon period, I will not call for a division. I thought Senator Coulter made out my case. I said that we understood there might have been up to 10 applicants who had been damaged by the cut-off date. Senator Coulter says that he thinks there are only two companies who had been damaged.
—He did not say `damaged'.
—Those are your words.

—He denies that they are damaged. He says that he thinks only two companies had applications pending. It seems to me grossly unfair that those companies should be cut off at the knees because the Government happened to pick on 3 June. After all, if that had been a non-sitting week it might very well have been 10 June before the Government introduced its Bill in the chamber. We are talking about 3 June 1988 because there were so many defects in the Bill which the Government introduced at that stage that it has taken it 12 months to fix it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Two weeks in a row, in answer to questions by Senators Beahan and Giles, Senator Cook misrepresented my public statements on the benefits of chelation therapy for people suffering from cardiovascular disease and other circulatory problems. Firstly, Senator Cook said that my statements were based on anecdotal evidence. They are not. They are based on extensive research conducted by the Cypher Corporation in the United States of America and by cardiovascular surgeons and general practitioners-to name just a few.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook admitted that the Government permits ethylene diamine tetra acetate for the treatment of patients with heavy metal poisoning. Yet he claimed that I am promoting a dangerous substance. Senator Cook's statement is contradictory and simply untrue. Senator Cook also claimed that I am promoting a miracle cure or wonder drug. That is not so. I have always maintained that all research shows that it helps only between 80 per cent and 90 per cent of patients which, I might add, is a very high percentage. Senator Cook also claimed that the only way for it to be approved was by proper trialling. That is not so. Penicillin and Digoxine did not have double-blind trials done in Australia before approval.

Senator Cook also claimed that I said that Australia was the only country in the world not allowing chelation. He quoted a Hansard interjection from 9 June. However, try as hard as Hansard does, not all interjections are reported totally accurately. I have never said that. I would never say such a thing as I know more about the subject than the Minister for Resources is ever likely to know. That statement is simply not true. What I have said is that it is used widely all around the world: in the United Kingdom, Europe, the United States of America and New Zealand-just to name a few. Senator Cook also stated that I should provide to the relevant Minister any information that I have available, as if I had not already done so. Unfortunately, he is obviously not bright or thorough enough to have found out that I have already done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. A personal explanation should be a personal explanation, not a debate about a Minister's virtues.
—Senator Knowles, you should confine yourself to where you have been misrepresented and not debate the matter.

—I am attempting to do that by stating what the Minister has said and, in fact, what I have said and done. As I say, the Minister has not found out that I have already done what he has suggested in providing the Minister with any information. I have done that, as have medical practitioners as recently as the last seven months.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very sorry that Senator Giles and Senator Cook have seen fit to make this important issue of chelation therapy a political issue. I have raised this matter purely as a matter of public health and of the right of patients to choose treatment. Unquestionably there is overwhelming evidence worldwide to substantiate the claims that I have made about chelation therapy and I believe that it is scurrilous in the extreme for Senators Cook, Beahan and Giles to say repeatedly in the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Knowles, there has been a ruling on a previous point of order. When you make a personal explanation you must confine yourself to what was said and what the correct version is-not any comments on the nature of the allegations.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. As I say, Senators Cook, Beahan and Giles have said repeatedly in the Senate that I am giving people false hope and that there is no other way of approving this drug. That is simply not so. I am very much aware-notwithstanding Senator Cook's assertions to the contrary-that it would be highly desirable for the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee to approve the treatment. That is exactly what I have sought since the last evaluation was done in 1983-six years ago. It is quite untrue to say that I have not sought those procedures. It is also quite untrue to say that I am unaware of the benefits. It is also quite untrue to say that the drug that I am promoting is dangerous. I hope that honourable senators would, first of all, learn how to pronounce the name of the drug.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.57 to 2 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to Amendments Nos 1, 2 and 4 made by the Senate and disagreed to Amendment No. 3.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the message be considered in the Committee of the Whole forthwith.
Consideration of House of Representatives message.
Amendment to which the House of Representatives has disagreed-
No. 3-Page 21, after clause 38, insert the following new clause:
Limitation of effect
``38a. (1) The amendments of the Principal Act contained in sections 37 and 38 of this Act shall, unless sooner repealed, cease to have effect on and from the day next following 30 June 1990.

``(2) On and from the day next following 30 June 1990 the provisions in the Principal Act amended by sections 37 and 38 of this Act shall revive in the form in which they exist on the day before the commencement of this Act.''.
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to amendment No. 3 of the Senate
Senate amendment No. 3 is not acceptable because:

(1) Appropriate Government consideration of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, proper consultation with all interested professional organisations, industry bodies and the wider community, preparation and passing of legislation could not occur by 1 July 1990.

(2) Uncertainty will be created for health funds with the result that the proposed benefits for contributors generally through lower and/or more stable contribution rates will not occur. This continuing uncertainty will maintain the current disincentive to insure the aged.

(3) The threat of a possible return to the current reinsurance arrangements will undermine the reinforcement of the community rating principle which the legislation is designed to achieve. The implications of the ``Sunset'' provisions will mean significantly higher health insurance contributions for older Australians when the current reinsurance arrangements apply again after 1 July 1990.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the Committee does not insist upon amendment No. 3, made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House of Representatives has returned to the Senate the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 indicating that it has agreed to three of the four amendments made by the Senate: the two related to the introduction of the vocational register and differential payment of fees to general practitioners and the introduction of the 008 number for access to departmental officers, and the provision whereby a sunset clause was to be imposed upon the new health reinsurance arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is very pleased that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has indicated that he accepts the amendments made in relation to general practitioners and is very grateful for the indication by the Minister of the Government's willingness to cooperate with the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance which has been established. I heard the Minister in the course of his remarks in the House of Representatives refer to the question of possible extension of the terms of reference of that Committee in respect of the work that it needs to do in looking at insurance and reinsurance arrangements. I indicate to the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) that the Opposition will be more than happy to facilitate at some later stage any expansion of the terms of reference in line with the comments that the Minister made in the House of Representatives. Nevertheless, we are very pleased that amendments Nos 1 and 2 have been adopted. We believe that they will substantially improve the health care system in Australia.

The House of Representatives has disagreed to amendment No. 3 for the reasons which are set forth in the schedule attached to its message. Basically it says that the Government does not believe that it could respond to the Senate committee report between the time of its reporting in March and the operation of the sunset clause on 1 July. We do not believe that the Government cannot respond within that period of time.

The House of Representatives committee of reasons then says that uncertainty would be created for health funds and that proposed benefits would flow to contributors. We believe that it is a quite specious argument for the reasons that were set out at some length in the course of the debate.

Thirdly, the House of Representatives says that the threat of a possible return to the current reinsurance arrangements will undermine the reinforcement of the community rating principle which the legislation is designed to achieve. We reject that as an argument. We have consistently said-and I repeated it in the debate yesterday-that the Opposition is fully in support of the principle of community rating and has not sought in any way to derogate from the principle of community rating.

Nevertheless, the Opposition has throughout made it clear that it wishes to see passage of this Bill. It contains a number of desirable elements, including those related to pathology tables and services and amendments to the Nursing Homes Act. We have two Senate inquiries as a result of the passage of this Bill: one by a standing committee which will deal with certain nursing home matters and one by the select committee which has been established and to which amendments Nos 1 and 2 to which the House of Representatives has now agreed relate. Because we wish to secure the passage of the Bill and believe that it is important, although we reject each of the three reasons given by the Government in disagreeing with the Senate amendment No. 3, it is not the intention of the Opposition to press the amendment calling for the sunset clause and I therefore indicate that the Opposition will support the motion moved by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are disappointed that a deal has been done between the Government and the Opposition on this matter. The arguments which Senator Puplick has just brought out are certainly those that he used yesterday to support the sunset clause. I would again like to run through the three reasons which the House of Representatives gives. I suppose it is more proper to say that the Government members of the House of Representatives gave those reasons because I do not imagine that the Opposition there supported them. It would have been Government members of the House of Representatives who put forward the reason that there was insufficient time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has three members on the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. Those three members presumably will speak with their colleagues during the time that evidence is being taken and will indicate the way that evidence is pointing. The Government will also be aware of that evidence and, even before the Committee reports, presumably will be shaping up towards some sort of a reconsideration of what could be put in place to better serve the interests of both the public and the private insurance industries. The requirement for some continuing access to the existing arrangements would be quite easily met, if the Government did not have sufficient time, by merely bringing in an amending Bill which would contain clauses 37 and 38 and give an extension of time to those. There are a number of ways in which the Government could adequately deal with that time constraint.

I pointed out yesterday that the uncertainty for the health funds has been created by the Government itself, which has repeatedly and consistently changed the rules over all the years that it has been in office. Through doing that it has made it very difficult for private insurance companies to properly calculate their actuarial scales, to set packages of private insurance and calculate the premiums. The creation of the Committee which is reconsidering this matter is itself the mechanism which ensures the continuing uncertainty of that for a time. But, hopefully, within 12 months one will get out of this consideration by the Committee something which would better serve the health insurance industry, both public and private, so that at least a time limit is set on that uncertainty.

The deletion of the sunset clause has the effect of extending the period of uncertainty. If we are right, what the Government is now doing is simply applying a bandaid to the industry without any long term benefits. Unless the Government acts quickly the uncertainty will be extended by the deletion of the sunset clause. In relation to a threat to a possible return to the current reinsurance arrangements, the Bill ignores the fact that those arrangements include the principle of community rating. The Government has chosen to extend that principle in a particular way. There are other ways in which the community rating principle could have been extended. Hopefully, those possible alternatives will be looked at by the Senate Select Committee and recommendations will be made to incorporate the community rating principle. Like the Opposition, the Australian Democrats totally support that principle, but would extend it in a way that would better serve both public and private insurance.
We are disappointed, as I have indicated, that the Opposition seems to have done a deal with the Government on this. We believe that the sunset clause does not act in the way in which--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the only ones allowed to do deals, aren't you?

—Senator Panizza is not the only one who can make those sorts of claims. Clearly we have an example of a deal being done between the Government and the Opposition. It is a deal which the Opposition has done with the Government to get this piece of legislation through. There are no other words for it so Senator Panizza should not try to get of the hook. We are not supporting the deletion of the sunset clause but we will not seek to divide on the matter because quite clearly the Government and the Opposition will join forces to pass it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick has provided a lucid exposition of what is involved here. I do not intend to go back over that but I intend to acknowledge with thanks his comment about the extension of the terms of reference of the Senate select committee. We would like to include public and private hospitals because we believe they are the major contributors to the health insurance costs. That is a matter for some further discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also advised that in terms of what Senator Coulter has said the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has said that he will consider the recommendations of the Senate select committee in the context of Medicare generally. I do not wish to add any more to the debate other than to say--
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot resist this comment. Senator Coulter talked about a deal. I do not think Senator Coulter should raise that issue in this chamber because everyone at different times has been party to a deal.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clause 16 (Reference of resource matter to Commission).

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying when this debate was interrupted earlier, this amendment is a very simple one. It just requires the Commonwealth Minister to consult with the governments of the States or Territories that may be affected by the inquiry. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has, in effect, acknowledged that that is reasonable but claims that he will do it anyway. I put it to the Minister that in a federation where one has a constitution which sets out the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth and the States it is not adequate for the Minister to just say, `Well, of course, we will do that anyway. We are dealing with this Bill in a situation where we could easily put this amendment in and it would be acceptable'. I must refer to something Senator Sanders said in relation to this matter during the second reading debate when he said in effect-I cannot quite recall the precise words; but I think he would acknowledge this-that the best thing that could happen in Australia was the abolition of the States. I see that Senator Sanders is nodding his head and giving me the thumbs up sign to indicate that he supports that.
—He represents the State of Tasmania.

—That is exactly the point I want to make. Currently Senator Sanders represents the State of Tasmania which he represents by not being in Tasmania but by living in the Australian Capital Territory. Let me go a step further and say to the people of the Australian Capital Territory that Senator Sanders will be putting himself up as a candidate for the Australian Capital Territory at the next Senate election. Clearly he wants to abolish the States. The people of the Australian Capital Territory should be aware that he will no doubt also want to abolish the Territories, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. He signals that he approves of that. That will be the policy that he will put before the people of the Australian Capital Territory at the next election-if elected he will support the abolition of the Australian Capital Territory. I hope that my colleague Senator Reid has noted that for her campaign speeches. Undoubtedly it is something that we should be shouting far and wide to the people of the Australian Capital Territory.
—He will dump them as he dumped Tasmania.
—I agree. If the people of the Australian Capital Territory were silly enough to elect him and if he gets the opportunity to dump them, he will dump them as he has dumped the Tasmanians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am about to engage in an unorthodox practice. The amendment moved by Senator Lewis is paragraph (1a) of the document circulated. If I may, Mr Chairman, I will ask Senator Lewis, through you, whether he would regard this wording as having met his point on consultation:

SPEECH.PARA: (1a) Before the Minister refers a resource matter to the Commission, the Minister shall:
(a) consult with the governments of the States; and
(b) take reasonable steps to consult with persons who are, in the opinion of the Minister, interested in the resource matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes.

—I then say that the Government, of course, would reserve its right to consult with appropriate organisations. Some of those organisations are ones which have lobbied us over this legislation. They mainly include organisations which have lobbied the Australian Democrats. That would enable the full-blown, all-singing, all-dancing, all-laughing consultation to precede any reference of a matter. All parties should be assuaged by that and sleep easily in their beds at night because of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend my amendment to adopt the words which the Minister has suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, after subclause 16 (1), the following new subclause:
``(1a) Before the Minister refers a resource matter to the Commission, the Minister shall:
(a) consult with the governments of the States; and
(b) take reasonable steps to consult with persons who are, in the opinion of the Minister, interested in the resource matter.''.

I just draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the words are `consult with the States'. In my amendment I actually used the words `to consult with the Government of each State or Territory that may be affected by the inquiry'. I think the words that the Minister is suggesting would require him to consult with say all of the States. If the Minister is happy with that, I am quite happy to accept those words.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy with that. We are wanting to take a national view of these things. We do not want a basis on which some States could say, `We do have an interest that you did not consider when you consulted with State X and therefore we were left out of the consultation round'. We want this to be a complete consultation.
—The words actually used are `the States'. I would like the amendment to read `the States and Territories'.
—Senator Lewis, you are perfectly entitled to amend your amendment as you like. But in the definitions of this Bill `States' includes Territories.
—I accept the words.

—I believe that there should be consultation. I am pleased that the Government includes in this consultation process groups which-I believe these are the words-are `involved or interested'. Without having the piece of paper in front of me, I am not quite sure of the exact wording. I take it then that I have the Government's assurance, through the Minister for Resources, that this will include environmental groups and other interested bodies.
—I indicate for the record that yes, it does.

—I do not have the piece of paper in front of me either. I would like to know who will be included and excluded under the term `interested bodies'. It seems to me that in this place the only interested bodies are environmental groups. However, there are other groups that are very interested: primary industries, the mining industry and so on. Will the Minister tell us which bodies are included in `interested bodies'? I would like the Minister to define that for me. A Minister like Senator Cook may be wide-embracing, but if we have a narrow-minded Minister it is up to him or her who will and who will not be heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for his vote of confidence in me as Minister. I agree that I am not a narrow-minded Minister. The wording of the provision will enable, given the nature of the reference being proposed, consultation with those organisations or individuals who have clearly an interest in that reference. They would need to be, in my view, a legitimate, bona fide organisation, or a person with a national reputation, that is worthy of consultation. The Government is saying that before it would refer those references, it would consult broadly. Senator Sanders asked whether that includes environmental organisations as that is of particular interest to him. My answer was that yes, it does. Senator Panizza asked me whether it included industry organisations, be they primary industries or mining industries. My answer is that yes, it does. As to who is consulted, that depends on the nature of the reference being transmitted to the Commission. Therefore, this answer should not be taken to mean that in all cases all of those organisations would be consulted. The appropriate ones would be appropriate to the reference.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether a more narrow-minded Minister would replace me in the future, that is a matter that is in the hands of the electors and the Prime Minister who appoints positions in Cabinet. I expect to be here a long time.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 8, clause 30, line 29, leave out ``Where a person'', insert ``Subject to subsection (2), where a person''.
(3) Page 9, at end of clause 30, add the following new subclause:
``(2) Subsection 32 (3) applies to written evidence or a document of the kind referred to in subsection (1), as if the written evidence or document were a draft report.''.
(4) Page 9, subclause 31 (2), line 9, leave out ``The Commission shall'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3), the Commission shall''.

``(3) Subsection 32 (3) applies to a background paper as if it were a draft report.''.
(6) Page 9, subclause 32 (2), line 15, leave out ``The Commission shall'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3), the Commission shall''.
(7) Page 9, after subclause 32 (2), add the following new subclauses:
``(3) The Commission must not make available to the public any part of a draft report that discloses information, if:
(a) the person responsible for providing the information objects in writing to the information being made public; and
(b) the information relates to the person; and
(c) the information is not already (by whatever means) in the public domain; and
(d) the information discloses:
(i) trade secrets; or
(ii) any other information of commercial value to the person that would be, or could reasonably be expected to be, destroyed or diminished by being made public; or

(iii) information (other than trade secrets or information to which subparagraph (ii) applies) concerning a person in respect of the person's business, commercial, financial or professional affairs, being information the disclosure of which would, or could reasonably be expected to, unreasonably affect the person adversely in respect of any of those affairs.
``(4) For the purposes of subsection (3) `person' includes:
(a) a natural person;
(b) a corporation; or
(c) an unincorporated body.''.
(8) Page 9, at end of clause 35, add the following new subclauses:

``(2) Unless the Minister certifies that it would be contrary to the public interest for information not to be disclosed in the report, subsection 32 (3) applies to a report as if it were a draft report.

``(3) A Ministerial certificate under subsection (2) is to be laid before each House of the Parliament on the sitting day immediately before the day on which the Minister lays before that House a report to which the certificate relates.''.
(9) Page 10, subclause 36 (1), line 3, leave out ``Where the Commission'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3), where the Commission''.
(10) Page 10, after subclause 36 (2), add the following new subclause:
``(3) The Commission must not require a person to give evidence, or produce a signed statement or any document, at a public hearing, if:
(a) the person so requests in writing; and
(b) the evidence, statement or document, contains information of a kind referred to in subsection 32 (3) of this Act.''.

The main purpose of these amendments is set out in amendment No. 7, which relates to the addition of proposed new subsections to be inserted after subclause 32 (2). Amendment No. 8 is a qualifying amendment. The change sounds fairly complicated but it really is fairly simple. The truth is that we are trying to protect commercial in-confidence evidence and commercial in-confidence documents which witnesses who come before the Resource Assessment Commission may be required to give, or may give voluntarily, which, of course, is the best way for it to be given, but given on the basis that they know it will be kept confidential to the Commission. There is ultimately an overriding provision which would enable the Minister at the end of the day to disclose the information if it was believed to be essential in the public interest. Actually, it is put in the reverse: that it would not be contrary to the public interest for information not to be disclosed. In any event there is an overriding clause.

We put it to the Committee that there will be evidence of capital investment, that there will be evidence of profits, that there will be projections of profits by some companies, and they may wish to keep it commercially confidential. As I indicated during my speech on the second reading, there may be new techniques or new technologies which they may wish to use. One can imagine that, as the years go on, further techniques will arise in the mining industry in particular, and that there may be some commercial advantage in the companies keeping these techniques or technologies secret until such time as they have entered into the public domain.

We put it to the Committee that it would be reasonable and proper that the Bill enable this sort of commercial in-confidence material to be kept so by the Commission. I am sure that it would be to the advantage of the Commission to be able to assure witnesses that their information could be kept commercial in-confidence to encourage them to be quite open about the sort of evidence they would be prepared to provide to the Commission. It is the sort of thing that we believe should have been considered by a Senate committee in the first place, but as the Government and the Democrats have combined to prevent the referral of this Bill to a Senate committee, the Opposition has put forward the amendments at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support these amendments. In the past we have often been involved in situations where the excuse of so-called proprietary information has been used to prevent valuable data, which was essential to the discussion of the resource, from being made public. I can quote two instances, one being the case of the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania during the dams dispute. It never did reveal the price of power to the major users of power. When it finally did come up, it turned out that it was well below the cost of generation; it was a massive subsidy to Comalco Ltd, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd and all the other major users in Tasmania. Obviously, if we are to have a resource/environment discussion we must know the basic economics.

SPEECH.PARA: Another instance, which is more current, is that we still do not know how much the Japanese are actually paying for the woodchips taken out of the south-east forests of New South Wales. This is so-called proprietary information. But, if we are going to frame an argument or discussion about the value of an industry in economic terms versus the environmental damage, we must have this information available in trying to come to some rational conclusion. It must be public information. For that reason we are not supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is sensitive to the issue about commercial confidentiality that has been raised by Senator Austin Lewis. I will quickly say why we wish to keep the present arrangements and reject these amendments. First, we are relatively sure that industry is relaxed about the present arrangements. We have consulted, as best we can, a number of bodies in the period since we became aware of these amendments. None of them have raised any serious difficulty. From that point of view, we believe that the existing proposal is adequate.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the existing proposal matches that already operating in the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). The IAC has been around for about 20 years. There have been no problems about its observance of commercial confidentiality. There has been no scandal. We think that that is a reasonable model and we see no reason to change. We cite a further reason. Some of the users of this Commission may be people who are used to the IAC procedures. A degree of familiarity with those procedures is probably an advantage in that, if there is a congruence between both, at least people who use both know what those procedures are and they are clear. For those reasons, we reject the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I can still count. The Australian Democrats will not support the amendments. The Government will not support the amendments. I will not waste the time of the Parliament by calling for a division. I indicate how unhappy we are that the Government has not seen fit to put these amendments into the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 18, subclause 56 (3), line 9, leave out ``within 25 sitting days'', insert ``within 15 sitting days''.
(2) Page 19, Schedule 2, leave out ``Long Title'', insert ``Title''.
The first amendment relates to the annual report. Clause 56 (3) on page 18 of the Bill states:
The Minister shall cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 25 sitting days of that House after the day on which the Minister received the report.

Twenty-five sitting days is an enormous amount of sitting days. After all, we sit only eight days in a four-week period. So we are really looking at a possibility of the report being tabled 14, maybe 16, weeks after the Minister gets it. I see no reason why the Senate should wait 25 sitting days. Accordingly, I have moved the amendment for a requirement that the report be tabled within 15 sitting days. The Minister would then have up to two months in which to table the report. That would be a much more reasonable time for the Senate and the other House to receive the report.

The other amendment is to correct what is really a mistake in some draftsman's book of precedents. A Bill has a title; it does not have a long title. It happens to have a short title as well. But it does not necessarily have a long title just because it has a short title. Occasionally we tend to call it the long title but we really mean the title to the Bill. My second amendment corrects that by deleting the words `Long Title' in the second schedule and substituting the correct expression of `Title'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the second amendment but not the first amendment. There is no need for me to delay the Committee with a long speech as to the reasons why. The second amendment is simply a correction of the legal title of the Act-the long or the short of it. In this case it should simply be `Title' and not `Long Title'.

—I find Senator Lewis's argument about the 15 sittings days quite persuasive. I must say that I read this in great haste and I thought that there was not very much difference between 25 days and 15 days, but in politics 25 sitting days can be an eternity.
—Especially with a winter recess.
—The winter recess-the winter of our discontent. I indicate to the Committee that we support the Opposition's amendments and wish that the Commission would report within 15 sitting days.
—I thought we had the numbers on this because I thought we had a signal from the Australian Democrats that they were going to support us.
—I just misunderstood. I did not notice the word `sitting'.
—I see. It occurs to me that we have lost, in which case rather than the Opposition do it to us we will do it to ourselves. We accept the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —That begs the question as to why `25 sitting days' was put in in the first place. It is important that in future the drafters of these measures realise that 15 sitting days is the regular period normally included in disallowance provisions, and so on, in legislation. I wondered why it was put in in the first place. It is important that this was picked up by the Opposition, and I am supporting it. It looks as though it is unanimous.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 9, after clause 30 insert the following new clause:
Australian Heritage Commission to give evidence

``30a. Where a matter relating to the national estate, within the meaning of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, is relevant to an inquiry, the Australian Heritage Commission shall give evidence about the matter to the inquiry.''.
(3) Page 10, clause 37, lines 26 to 29, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Allowances to persons giving evidence
``37. (1) A person who appears at a hearing because of a notice under subsection 36 (1) is entitled to be paid such allowances for the person's travelling and other expenses as are prescribed.

``(2) If the Chairperson considers it appropriate, a person who appears at a hearing to give evidence or produce documents (otherwise than because of a notice under subsection 36 (1)) may be paid such allowances for the person's travelling and other expenses as are prescribed.
``(3) If the Chairperson considers it appropriate, a person who gives evidence to, or produces documents at, an inquiry may be:
(a) paid such remuneration as is prescribed for the performance of work involved in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents; or
(b) reimbursed such expenses, or compensated for such losses, as were reasonably incurred in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents;
or both.
``(4) Money payable under this section is to be paid by the Commonwealth.''.
(4) Page 17, clause 55, line 37, leave out ``not'', insert ``neither in derogation of nor''.
(5) Page 19, Schedule 1, leave out principles 1, 2 and 3, insert the following principles:

``1. There should be an integrated approach to conservation (including all environmental and ecological considerations) and development by taking both conservation (including all environmental and ecological considerations) and development aspects into account at an early stage.

``2. Resource use decisions should seek to optimise the net benefits to the community from the nation's resources, having regard to efficiency of resource use, environmental considerations, ecological integrity and sustainability, ecosystem integrity and sustainability, the sustainability of any development, and an equitable distribution of the return on resources.

``3. Commonwealth decisions, policies and management regimes may provide for additional uses that are compatible with the primary purpose values for the area, recognising that in some cases both conservation (including all environmental and ecological considerations) and development interests can be accommodated concurrently or sequentially, and, in other cases, choices must be made between alternative uses or combinations of uses.''.

Amendment No. 2 is basically a continuation of my first amendment, which related to the Australian Heritage Commission. It would allow that Commission to be involved in a matter before the Commission which relates to the National Estate. Amendment No. 3 relates to giving people who have appeared before the Commission or who have prepared material for the Commission some recompense or remuneration for their activities. Amendment No. 4 is also related to that. Amendment No. 5 involves lofty principles. I shall not go through them in detail. They involve the idea of sustainability, ecosystem integrity and other such concepts which, I am glad to say, can now be included in legislation. For too long we have had legislation which was divorced from the real world. The concept of sustainability and ecological integrity will become a standard clause in Bills, I believe, as we learn more about the workings of our environment and how fragile it is. I commend these sentiments and these amendments to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to give the Committee an explanation of what he believes is the Government's explanation of the language which is adopted in these amendments. This is important from the point of view of statutory interpretation, now that the courts are entitled to take into consideration the debate in the chamber on the meaning of words. In particular, I refer to Democrat amendment No. 5 about the principles to be inserted in the Bill. In principle No. 1 of Schedule 1, the main change is to include after the word `conservation' the words in brackets `including all environmental and ecological considerations'. That also occurs in principle No. 3. Principle No. 2 of Schedule 1 refers to words we heard Senator Sanders tell us during the second reading debate are words that everyone knows the meaning of because they are used in some book that he referred to. I would be very interested to know what the Minister thinks the High Court of Australia would interpret them as meaning. In particular, I find the word `sustainability' fascinating. I have my doubts as to what its meaning might be. I ask the Minister to express his views as to the meaning of the words. What does `ecological integrity' mean? What does `ecosystem integrity' mean? What does `sustainability' mean? What does the Minister consider to be the meaning of the phrases `the sustainability of any development' and `an equitable distribution of the return on resources'? I think there will be great arguments before the High Court of Australia in due course as to the meaning of all of those words and expressions. I would be interested to hear what the Minister thinks they might mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a few questions and make a few comments on these amendments. Amendment No. 1 moved by the Australian Democrats seeks to insert `the Australian Heritage Commission' into clause 14 of the Bill. We got rid of that amendment. Amendment No. 2 inserts a new clause regarding the Australian Heritage Commission. The amendments seek to put the Australian Heritage Commission in a privileged position, above many other organisations. Amendment No. 3 concerns `remuneration as is prescribed for the performance of work involved in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents'. I note that this applies only if the chairperson so agrees or considers it appropriate. The obligation to consider whether it is appropriate certainly puts a load on the chairperson.

SPEECH.PARA: This could be an open cheque book for anyone who may wish to prepare a case to put before the Commission for any reason whatsoever. Most of the radical splinter groups, which will be putting submissions before the Commission, will be doing so only for the purpose of locking up resources, not opening them up. I would like to know what sort of an open cheque book will result from these provisions and whether they will result in open slather for these radical splinter groups to stop Australia's progress.

Senator Lewis asked the Minister for an interpretation of the words in amendment No. 5 `including all environmental and ecological considerations'. If one wants those principles to apply, other principles should also be included in the legislation, the main consideration being the return to the Australian people on Australia's resources, resources which under this legislation we will not be able to make use of. Plenty of others could do so. Senator Lewis questioned the meaning of the word `equitable' in this amendment, as part of the phrase `equitable distribution'. I question the word `distribution'. Who do the Democrats have in mind that the return on resources be distributed to? It could be distributed widely. I probably have different ideas from the Minister and the Democrats regarding how the return on resources will be distributed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. That is because we are a reasonable government, open to persuasion by logical argument. We are interested in reconciliation. For all of those obvious reasons-reasons for which we are well known-we accept the amendments. Let me go to the questions that have been asked by honourable senators opposite. A series of different amendments has been moved. It would be convenient for me to take them in the order in which they appear on the paper, which means that I will start with the questions raised by Senator Panizza and conclude with questions raised by Senator Austin Lewis. The first question Senator Panizza asked was why the Australian Heritage Commission is being required to be consulted.
—To be in a privileged position.

—We have dealt with the first part of that amendment. Let me deal with the second part of it. The Australian Heritage Commission is required under amendment No. 2 to appear before and make submissions to the Resource Assessment Commission when matters of the National Estate are being dealt with by the Resource Assessment Commission. We support this amendment. Whether this amendment were to be enforced or not, almost always the Australian Heritage Commission would wish to appear at such hearings. However this amendment, if enacted, would impose upon the Commission a statutory obligation to do so. In our view it is to the point that it should. The National Estate is something that the Australian Heritage Commission assesses. By undertaking that assessment and declaring areas or properties on the National Estate it tells Australia and the world what areas or properties of national significance in Australia ought to be conserved or protected. There is a whole body that argues whether the Commission makes the right judgment. I do not propose to enter into that argument. But the Commission is a government authority and is independent of ministerial direction. It makes its decisions on the evidence that it adduces and the scientific studies that it conducts. It seems appropriate, therefore, that it should have a statutory obligation to appear before the Resource Assessment Commission. We accept the amendment because of that.

SPEECH.PARA: If we go to amendment No. 3, the second point made by Senator Panizza is that an awful load is put on the Chairperson of the Resource Assessment Commission in determining whether people are entitled to payment or not. At first blush, it may appear to be true, but we appoint at a good salary people with a lot of experience and who have prestige and standing in the community to make responsible decisions. The least important decision that the Commission will make is whether people should be paid for coming before it. All its other decisions on how to balance environmental concerns and developmental concerns are of vastly greater importance in terms of the national good. So I do not think we can quibble with the quality of people who will be making these decisions. Therefore, I do not accept the argument that these people will not be able to make this particular class of decision. In the case of this particular class of decision, clearly the type of material that they present and its value to furthering the interests of the inquiry will be something to be taken into consideration when deciding whether they ought to be paid for preparing or presenting that and appearing to do so.

Given that we have got a wide range of organisations with various economic and financial capacity, from perhaps major mining houses on one side to a voluntary regional environmental group on the other, there should be some equality in being able to present an argument to the Commission and adduce information and facts. Because financially a local regional body may not have the capacity of a mining house to do that, there ought to be some means of evening up the scales so that the Commission can hear all the evidence. Let me now turn to the question of the meaning of these words--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your boss is coming in here to get you to hurry this up.
—The House of Representatives is waiting.

—The House of Representatives is waiting, but the Senate is used to causing it to do so. However, I will not delay the other place any further. This is an important question. I thank Senator Lewis for asking it. I now propose to answer it. In our view, there is no distinction or particular point to be drawn from the fact that some words that have been added appear in brackets and other words do not. The words that appear in brackets and the words that have been added that do not appear in brackets are, in our view, a more current usage of the language. The language that was in the original Bill was language which was drawn from the Australian conservation strategy. That is a document of some years back. The usage of terms in this area has altered since that time. It seems appropriate to us that we recognise that that is so, but we say that it does not add to the meaning of the words that are there. It expresses that meaning in a more modern or more current way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister believe that under amendment No. 2 the Australian Heritage Commission could in fact delay or hold up the inquiry if ever it refused to give evidence? That might very well put the Australian Heritage Commission in a situation where it could say, `Well, you're not going to complete this inquiry. We are not going to give evidence and, therefore, you cannot complete it'. That is the first point.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that this greedy amendment will enable people perhaps to spend three months at the Franklin River on the dole and then turn up at this inquiry and say, `Look, during that three months I spent at the Franklin River I gathered all this information about movement of the river and whether the water runs straight or crooked as it goes around bends. I want to give all this evidence to you'. At the end of that day, he can then take a payment. It has been put to me that what Minister Kerin was saying is that the Resource Assessment Commission would ask people to go away and collect evidence. Clearly, if they were to do that, I would have no objection to their being paid. But it was put that this did not mean a payment for past work that was not asked to be done.

This amendment moved by the Australian Democrats makes it quite clear that they may be reimbursed for such expenses or compensation for such losses as were reasonably incurred in collecting and preparing the evidence or documents. Such evidence might have nothing whatsoever to do with the sort of evidence that the Commission may have wanted. But the Commission would have to hear the evidence first. The Minister said that the Chairperson could reject these applications. With all due respect, can one imagine the Chairperson, on his or her very substantial salary, saying to these people, `We have heard your evidence and we are not going to allow you some claim for compensation.'? It is just defying the imagination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point on amendment No. 2 concerning the words `the Australian Heritage Commission shall give evidence'. Senator Lewis said that evidence could be held up forever and a day and that the Commission would never come to a finding. It is strange for people-or in this case a body-to be ordered to give evidence.

The other point is that people may not have any evidence to give anyhow. I bring the Minister back to my question about equitable distribution, which he still has not answered.

—I am sorry, I asked the Minister a question. That is not our fault; that is the Government's fault. It is a case of mismanagement of business. I ask that the Minister be given an opportunity to answer the question.

—I wasn't barracking you to hurry up.

—Okay. The first question was: can the Australian Heritage Commission, by not being ready, seek to delay or hold up indefinitely the proceedings? The word `shall' should be read as meaning that it shall do what is required by that provision. Whether it wants to or not, as Senator Panizza says-I draw the same conclusion as Senator Panizza; it is probably in the interests of the industry rather than the interests of the environment that it be heard-the Australian Heritage Commission is an authority set up under an Act by the Commonwealth with particular purposes. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis's second question was about the provision of allowances or disbursement for witnesses.
