SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my first remarks on the adjournment debate to the child migrant scheme. This is a scheme about which very little was known until comparatively recently. Between 1938 and 1967, the Australian and British governments arranged to resettle orphaned and abandoned children from the United Kingdom (UK) and Ireland into Australia under the Empire Resettlement Acts of 1922 and 1937. About 119 child migrant boys came to Western Australia in 1938. They went to the Christian Brothers Institution at Tardun. There were much earlier intakes into Fairbridge Boys Farm which was run under an Anglican scheme. In 1944, Mr Chifley, then Treasurer in the Curtin Labor Government, proposed a scheme to bring 50,000 war orphans to Australia. When he became Prime Minister, he appointed Mr Calwell immigration Minister and a much grander immigration policy was implemented at that time. The post-war child migrant scheme was a segment of this particular policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Catholic child migrants were transported to Western Australia under the Catholic episcopal migrant scheme of Western Australia Inc. The first child migrants arrived in Fremantle on the SS Asturias on 22 September 1947. After the formalities and fingerprinting, they were interned in various institutions. This scheme has been labelled `the last of the transportations' because in many ways these children were, unfortunately, treated like prisoners. They went to various institutions in Western Australia, various Catholic institutions such as Castledare, Clontarf, Bindoon, and Tardun which were run by the Christian Brothers. The girls went to St Josephs Orphanage, Wembley, and Nazareth House, Geraldton. The Anglican children went to the Fairbridge Farm. It would seem that New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia were the only States originally to participate in the child migrant scheme, although there are reports that girls from Nazareth House in Geraldton were later transported to a similar institution in Melbourne. It is possible that the other States could have been involved directly.

On arrival, the Catholic child migrants, at least, came under the complete care and control of the various institutions although control should have been vested in a department or office under the Western Australian Under-Secretary of Lands and Surveys. In about 1952, when some of the child migrants were approaching working age and about to leave the institutions, control was transferred to the Child Welfare Department which approached the institutions for details and particulars of the child migrants in their charge with varying degrees of success. Files were commenced on child migrants by the Department only in 1952-seven years after the first arrivals. In that year the British Government banned the further transportation of child migrants under this scheme, although other groups came to Australia under different schemes until 1968. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Regulations. These are the Statutory Rules 1946. Rule No. 7 says:
An authority in respect of any State shall, in relation to immigrant children in that State, keep a Register of Custodians in which he shall enter-
(a) the name, address, occupation and religion of every custodian;
(b) the name of every child in the custody of each custodian;
(c) the age, sex and religion of each such child;
(d) the names, addresses and occupations of the parents or guardians of the child in the United Kingdom;
(e) the date of arrival of the child in Australia, and the name of the ship in which the child arrived; and
(f) such other particulars as the Minister determines.

Now a lot of these past child migrants are adults. They are searching for their records-and, indeed, for their very identity in many cases-and the sad and sorry story is that they are simply not available. There are some very sad cases indeed, some of which have been publicised.

Recently in the United Kingdom a television program entitled Lost Children of the Empire was screened. This program was described by television critic Bernard Workman in the Universe on 14 May 1989 in this way:
The stories of these children, some old now, haunted me long after the midnight hour.
They were the stuff of nightmares, except who would dream that we would treat our own kith and kin so?
Why, right up to the mid-1960s, were we dumping these unwanted, largely unloved little ones-many under the age of 10-on uncaring societies half a world away?

They came from orphanages, from institutions and they were pushed out of Britain. They went with Government blessing sent by, among others, such sturdy institutions as Barnardo's, the Fairbridge Society, the Catholic Church, in the pious belief they were giving them a better start to life.
Instead, they were treated as slaves in Canada and Australia where they were made to work for a pittance, enduring beatings, privation and sexual abuse.

Many of these lost souls are sill searching for their roots, like the man, white haired now, weeping over his mother's grave. `I wish I'd found you while you were living . . . You could have told me who I am; that is important to me, to know who I am'.

On the same page of that paper there is a story about 56-year-old Gordon Grant who describes himself as being dumped at the age of one, with his six-year-old sister, in an orphanage in South Wales. The article states:
At the age of 12, in 1946, he was told that 30 boys would be selected to go to Australia.

Our 12,000-mile sea voyage was very pleasant, good food and recreation activities we enjoyed, and the people were wonderful. But our illusions were shattered when we reached the port of Fremantle, Western Australia-within the hour following disembarkation we were all herded like cattle into a large disused woolstore where we were fingerprinted by six plain clothed policemen. The youngest children were a mere four years old.
I arrived at my new home, Boys Town, Bindoon, on 22 September 1947.

In the article he relates how his first couple of years were not too bad because he worked on a farm there. However, in February 1948 a new superior took over, Brother Paul Francis Keaney, the initiator of the development of a huge project for the settlement of underprivileged boys coming from the UK. Gordon Grant describes how under Father Keaney they were given the impossible task of building the whole of Bindoon Boys farm and school. Although in their early teens, they had to work very hard without proper safety regulations. This resulted in frequent cases of boys being maimed on the construction sites. John McGillion, as a 12-year-old lad, received serious spinal injuries and injuries to his legs. John Murphy had spinal injuries; Charles Penglaze had a broken leg; and Michael Sele had serious head injuries. All are now invalid pensioners. He goes into some detail of the sexual assault that those boys also suffered at that institution.

Another child migrant known as Geordie-his proper name is Lionel Welsh-has written a book, which I commend to honourable senators as it makes very interesting reading. Geordie was 11 years of age when he made the six-week boat trip from England to Australia in 1947. He too believed he was going to a land of milk and honey where children rode horses to school, but a rude shock awaited him also when he arrived at the desolate Boys Town at Bindoon. He ran away four years later and could never come to terms with the fact that he did not know exactly who he was, until now, because through a newly formed society, known as the Child Migrant Friendship Society of Western Australia (Inc.), he was able to trace his father. He did not actually manage to meet his father because he died before he could trace him, but through that tracing of his family he has been able to meet up with a half-brother. Geordie describes very well and graphically indeed the trauma that people go through when they have no identity that they can fall back on.

In the Women's Day magazine last year stories were told of other child migrants. Details were given of the suffering that they were put through in their adult life and how many child migrants have tried to hide the fact that they came to Australia as child migrants and therefore did not have an identity. Other stories have been related to me through this new society. I inform the Senate that all of these stories are tales of suffering. The new Child Migrant Friendship Society is seeking to find the records as far as is possible. The Secretary of the Society has written a letter to the Minister for Community Services in Western Australia, and the Minister replied:
. . . there is no record of a formal register of child migrants. There is, however, a system of Index Cards . . .
The Secretary of the Child Migrant Friendship Society also wrote to the Federal Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), and he replied:
Any individual wanting such documents may apply to the FOI section of the Department, but must do so on an individual basis, . . .

To form an agency to deal with child migrants as you suggest would unfortunately be impractical as the documents are scattered across many agencies, both private and public and due to the passing of time many may be in archives.

This is one of the problems that the child migrants have. What documentation there is, is scattered between various departments and is very difficult to find. The Child Migrant Friendship Society, which is now incorporated, has been set up as a self-help group. It has five main aims, and these are: firstly, to seek official recognition; secondly, to liaise with the Child Migrant Trust of England to locate lost family members of the child migrants; and to this end, thirdly, to set up a child migrant contact register; fourthly, to seek out and help those in need; and, fifthly, to conduct group therapy sessions. The estimation is that of the 50,000 or so child migrants in Australia, there are some 12,000 in Western Australia. The questions the society is asking and which have not yet been answered are: who exactly authorised the transportations; and why was such cruelty in the institutions condoned? It has two aims. The first is to put an end to the miserable existence which so many child migrants now have. Many of them have a history of being in and out of gaol because, having been brought up in institutions, they have found it very hard to adapt to life outside institutions. Many of them are homeless and live either on the streets or very roughly in hostels that are available. Many of them still have no identity, which leads to psychological problems. The aim is to be able to provide a comfortable hostel or home where they can all get together again-because they regard themselves as a family.

Their other aim is to be granted Australian citizenship. Honourable senators, believe it or not in this Year of the Citizen, these people came in as children without birth certificates and therefore without proper identification-and very often with their release from the United Kingdom signed `Mother Superior' and not by name. So no tracing was possible in that way. Many of these people have no identity and therefore, having been in Australia since childhood, seek Australian citizenship.

I know of one particular man who came over as a child migrant. He fought for this country in the Vietnam War. He was found guilty of some very minor offences, which actually concerned a matter of principle. I think my fellow Western Australians will know who I am talking about. This man was a street trader who fought against the Perth City Council's regulations when the council sought to ban street trading. When he applied for Australian citizenship he was told that Australian citizenship could not be granted to him for that reason.

Other people feel that they should be granted Australian citizenship as a right because they are Australians, having been brought to Australia as children. They seek a register, which perhaps can be put together at this stage if only all the records which are spread about everywhere can be put together. This is one of the reasons why I have chosen to talk about this group at this stage. It is really important that any organisation or persons who had contact with these children of the time and who have access to records should bring those forward.

I would now like to raise a longstanding problem which Senator Haines has raised on previous occasions in this place. Regrettably, the problem has not been resolved since Senator Haines last pressed the Government to do so, in November of last year. The Government's failure to act becomes more and more worthy of condemnation with the now inordinate passage of time. The case was a particularly unsavoury one of the sexual harassment of a female officer in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). Having joined the RAAF in 1980, the woman in question suffered a considerable amount of sexual harassment in 1982. Senator Haines has recounted the details of this story before. Having reported a particular incident of attempted rape, the woman was subjected to further harassment, both sexual and otherwise. She was finally forced out of the Air Force and into private life.

I digress at this stage to point out that the two officers concerned in this unpleasant affair, and some other people who had been involved in the harassment, were eventually dismissed or otherwise disciplined for their actions. This clearly demonstrates that the Air Force acknowledged that the woman had been subjected to the treatment she claimed, including a smear campaign about her sexual preferences. There is no question about this. She was shown to have been correct and the people concerned were disciplined. Even worse, as has been explained to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) before, the harassment continued after she left the RAAF and after she moved from one State to another. She was put under intolerable emotional and physical stress. Her marriage broke down and she lost a work contract as a result of the smear campaign to which I referred earlier.

In short, this woman has suffered appalling. Sexual assault, improper investigation of her private life, gross infringements of her civil liberties, smearing of her character, loss of employment and promotion opportunities, and stress and mental anguish are just some of the experiences about which she is quite justified in complaining. As so often happens in the area of sexual harassment, she has been made the scapegoat for the misconduct and guilt of others. Obviously, this sort of thing cannot be tolerated. In this instance the Government is in a position to do something about it. Both the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Defence Force Ombudsman have made strong recommendations for an ex gratia payment to the woman. The woman herself has contacted the Government. Senator Haines has made repeated representations on her behalf and I do so again on this occasion.

The Minister for Finance turned down an ex-gratia payment in the past because he alleged that the harassment took place before the Sex Discrimination Act came into force. This rationale is absurd. As the Minister is well aware, harassment of this woman continued after she left the Air Force and, significantly, after the Sex Discrimination Act was passed in December 1983. Just to cite one example, in June 1985 she lost a work contract when the contractor made inquiries about her previous employment and was informed by the relevant RAAF personnel section that she was a homosexual. As a result, she lost considerable weekly income.

Quite apart from the injustice of the situation, the continued harassment should make the Minister think again. His own argument concerning the Sex Discrimination Act is shot to pieces. The evidence is before the Government, as are the recommendations for payment to which I referred earlier. If ever there were a genuine case for an ex-gratia payment, I think it would be this one. The Government's failure to have made an ex-gratia payment is bad enough, but the amount of time it has delayed the matter is intolerable. I urge the Government in the strongest possible terms to set the matter right at last; to make an ex-gratia payment to the woman; and at least to redress partly the appalling treatment she has suffered over a long period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again Senator Michael Baume has jumped to the defence of Mr Pat Reeves. Senator Baume alleges that he has never met Pat Reeves. Yet, Mr Reeves has no more loyal and slavish a supporter than Senator Baume. It is incredible that Senator Baume has again supported Pat Reeves this afternoon. I do not know whether Senator Baume uses mental telepathy, but what we saw today was quite amazing for a person who has never met Pat Reeves. Someone must have put across points of view for Senator Baume to raise this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume alleges that Mr Reeves wants to go the Supreme Court to release a document. I assure the Senate that, if Mr Reeves has reached the point where he wants to release that document, I will go with him on Monday morning to ensure that it is released. That document has been kept in the confines of the Supreme Court at the request of Mr Pat Reeves's lawyers.

Let me move to another point raised by Senator Baume. This afternoon the honourable senator alleged in the Senate, through Pat Reeves, that some sort of deal was done to abolish penalty rates in respect of Pizza Hut employees. Senator Baume agreed with that. We all know that he does not support penalty rates. Not only do I and the Senate know that but also all the workers in the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia know it. Dual photos of Senator Baume and Pat Reeves are being circulated amongst the 50,000 members of that union in New South Wales.

Let us examine the Pizza Hut agreement. In 1987 Pepsico Australia Pty Ltd had workers in its new home delivery establishments who were award free-they had no penalty rates or anything. What did the union do? The union leadership-I, Ken Jeffrey, the Secretary, and Peter James, the Research Director-negotiated with Pepsico and we were able to get an agreement to cover those workers and ensure that they had an award. What were we able to negotiate for those workers? We negotiated an agreement. The management of Pepsico said that it would not have an agreement with the liquor trades union, with penalty rates; that it wanted the workers to remain award free. As a result of the liquor industries union saying that it would call a meeting of all Pizza Hut workers throughout New South Wales, the owners of Pepsico made an agreement with the union.

Let me make clear what that agreement was. Those workers had no Saturday and Sunday penalty rates. I am pleased to say that, following the agreement that was signed by the union, those members now enjoy the same penalty rates as all other workers throughout Australia. That includes time and a half for Saturday, time and three-quarters for Sundays, double time and half for public holidays, a guarantee of a minimum of 10 hours work per week and the elimination of junior employment. Prior to this agreement we had a situation where that company could employ all juniors, which is what is done at Kentucky Fried Chicken Pty Ltd and at other establishments. We were able to get a ratio of full time employees to casual employees. At the same time we were able to get an agreement in regard to the ratio of juniors to seniors.

It amazes me that Senator Baume time and time again jumps to his feet in defence of Pat Reeves. Pat Reeves has no more slavish worker for him than Senator Baume. Yet he has the audacity to stand up in this Senate and tell senators and the people of this country, in an attempt to influence a union election, that he has nothing to do with Pat Reeves. If Senator Baume has nothing to do with Pat Reeves, I suggest that he must have great mental telepathy. On that note, I would like to table the document which I have referred to so that honourable senators and those journalists who are standing behind Senator Baume waiting for these documents can see it. I seek leave to table the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —What document is that?
—It is a full page advertisement which will go in the papers this weekend. It is to the attention of members in the form of a letter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The workers in the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia and the workers throughout Australia will know exactly where they stand when they read this advertisement. I can understand the frustrations of Mr Pat Reeves. He has tried all ways and means as a vehicle to get his message across. It is a shame to think that Pat Reeves has to stoop to use an anti-penalty rate campaigner such as Senator Michael Baume to support his case. I do not want to go into Patrick Partners and matters such as that. I will do so at a later stage when my assistant finishes researching it. I am sure that when that comes out we will be talking not only about the abolition of penalty rates with the support of Senator Baume, but also about Patrick Partners and a lot of other matters. I thank the Senate for allowing me to put my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented. I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had better be a personal explanation.

—The Minister should not threaten me. The Minister has tried many times but it does not work. I have been accused, on no evidence, of being `a slavish supporter of Pat Reeves'. I advise the Senate that I am not a supporter of Pat Reeves. I have no interest in the outcome of the election campaign. I have never had an involvement or interest in the election of Mr Pat Reeves in the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. I have never, as I have said, met him. The allegation is totally, absolutely and once again false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express again my concern about the level of unemployment in the State of Tasmania. On this occasion I wish to point out that a statutory authority, Australia Post, is now contributing to that level of unemployment. It is doing so because it is embarking on a plan to further reduce jobs in the State of Tasmania by transferring to Victoria job functions which have always been performed in my State of Tasmania. It appears to have embarked on this process simply on the basis of two criteria, namely, efficiency and cost effectiveness. It is my view that it should not do that. It has a community responsibility to the people of Tasmania. It is, after all, in a privileged position-a monopoly position, in fact-in respect of many of its services.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer particularly to a memo dated 31 May 1989, addressed to State head office staff, which talks about the concept of shared finance and accounting services with Victoria. According to this memo, that means that the general ledger, accounts payable and payroll functions will operate on computers in Victoria, data entry and report printing will be undertaken in Tasmania, expenditure cheques will be prepared in and mailed from Victoria; and payslips and paysheets will be printed in Tasmania. The Postmaster's financial statement systems will be run in Victoria and Victoria will distribute postal stock and stationery directly to post offices in Tasmania. That has been done since the year dot in Tasmania. I will not delay the Senate now, but there are other corollaries. I suppose one could say that there will be a devastating result, not only for the individuals concerned but also for people who are interested in stamp collections and so on.

The accounts receivable will continue to operate in Tasmania for the time being, until that function is converted to a Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) system. The wages system also will continue for the time being until that is replaced by the DEC system. In other words, Australia Post, which has a community responsibility towards Tasmania, is deciding what it will do in regard to this very important issue of employment on the basis of only two factors-efficiency and cost effectiveness. If they are its criteria, why do we not look at the monopoly position of Australia Post? It has a monopoly position in respect of certain aspects of mail delivery. Because it has that monopoly position, which this Parliament has enabled it to maintain, it has a responsibility, in my view, to ensure that the people of Tasmania who pay the piper receive some recompense for that in the way of job opportunities. It is not only the jobs of the individuals who will be directly affected that are at stake, it is a fact that those positions, forever and a day, will not be available to young people in Tasmania. It is no wonder that the rate of unemployment is so high in Tasmania. There are other factors involved, but this--

TALK.START.PARA: —The same thing is happening in Canberra. That is why there is a high level of unemployment in Canberra. It is the same scenario. The Public Service is not employing young people.

—Senator Watson has raised another aspect about young people and the Public Service. Young people are not getting a fair go, but I do not want to go into that; I want to concentrate on this issue. I appeal to the responsible Minister to look at the question of employment and ask Australia Post to consider whether it has a community responsibility to ensure that there is a maintenance of employment in the areas which have traditionally-indeed always-been undertaken in our State.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia Post also has the responsibility to heed the comments and appeals from various community leaders from all sectors on this question. I believe that it has this responsibility and it should be asked to discharge it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The proposition being put by Senator Harradine appears to me to be this: Australia Post has a monopoly power and therefore the ability to exploit a fair bit of monopoly pricing, that it should use that monopoly pricing to institutionalise inefficiency in its internal operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Were any officers who were on recreation, sick, maternity, special, long service, or any other type of leave during 1988 employed as consultants for the Department while on leave either under their own name or under a business name, in which business they had an interest; if so, who were the officers concerned, for what purpose were they employed as consultants, what remuneration was paid for the consultancies and what was the type and duration of their leave.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No officers on leave were employed as consultants during 1988. However, enquiries have revealed that one officer in Queensland was engaged as legal counsel on a number of occasions while on leave made up of long service leave on full pay, annual leave and leave without pay. The total absence on these various forms of leave was from 12 August 1988 to 26 May 1989. The officer was engaged under his own name. He is Mr D. O'Gorman, a Senior Legal Officer in the Brisbane Office of the Australian Government Solicitor. He was engaged to advise and/or appear in various cases. To 12 April 1989 he had been engaged in 13 matters and had been paid a total of 14137.10. There may yet be further bills lodged. The officer was granted leave, and permission to engage in employment while on leave, under local delegation to allow him to gain experience at the private Bar which would be of long term benefit to the Department. In the event he resigned from 26 May 1989.

I regard it as inappropriate for an officer to be engaged as counsel while on paid leave from the Department and have instructed the Secretary of my Department that there are to be no further such engagements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 February 1989 (Hansard, page 20), Senator Macklin asked me a question without notice concerning the education of gifted and talented children. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has not taken action flowing from recommendations in the Report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children because:
education is primarily the responsibility of State Governments although the Commonwealth has fostered activity, debate and interest relating to the needs of gifted and talented children;

as a general principle the Commonwealth considers that the continuing provision for gifted and talented students should be made by school and system authorities from resources available to them. These resources include funding provided through Commonwealth general resources and specific purpose programs; and

the Commonwealth and States are examining, in the Australian Education Council context, the possibility of a national centre (or centres) focusing on research and training relating to the education of gifted children.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: School of Dentistry, University of Western Australia

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 June 1989 (Hansard, page 3534), Senator Panizza asked me a question without notice concerning funding for the School of Dentistry at the University of Western Australia. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There is absolutely no basis to the Senator's assertion that funding levels for tertiary institutions have been reduced and that the School of Dentistry at the University of Western Australia might close due to funding cuts.

In the 1988 Budget the Government announced a significant real increase in the funds available to the higher education system over the next triennium. An additional $870 million will be provided over the triennium resulting in the creation of an additional 49,000 student places and the commencement or completion of more than 100 new major building projects. The University of Western Australia will receive an additional $1.33 million in 1989 to increase its intake level by 150 places and further growth will be funded in 1990 and 1991. Capital funds will also be provided to enable a start to be made on a new biological science building to cost $6.24 million.

The discussions which the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University have been having concerning the possible merger of the two institutions were initiated by the institutions themselves. They are not being forced to amalgamate by the Federal Government but the Government has indicated that it would support such a merger.

The recent Report of the Task Force on Amalgamations in Higher Education recommended that an additional $6.45 million, comprising $1.95 million from the National Priority (Reserve) Fund and $4.5 million for capital projects, be provided to the two institutions. The Government's decisions on the recommendations of the Task Force's Report will be announced today.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport and Communications: Gold Coast Telephone Number

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 4 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department have a 008 number which may be used by Gold Coast residents who wish to contact officers of the Department in Brisbane; if so, is this number listed in the Gold Coast telephone directory; if not, will the number be listed in future editions of the Gold Coast telephone directory and what is the number.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Transport and Communications does not have a 008 telephone number available to Gold Coast residents who wish to contact departmental officers in Brisbane.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Aboriginal Affairs: Gold Coast Telephone Number

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department have a 008 number which may be used by local residents who wish to contact officers of the Department in Brisbane; if not, will the number be listed in future editions of the Gold Coast telephone directory and what is the number.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department does not have a 008 number for Gold Coast residents wishing to contact the Department in Brisbane. The Department has no toll free telephone numbers for any of its offices.
